{{Tone|date=December 2007}} {{Peacock|date=May 2017}} '''Business-IT alignment''' is a dynamic state in which a [[Company|business organization]] is able to use [[information technology]] (IT) to achieve business objectives - typically improved financial performance or marketplace [[competitiveness]]. Some definitions focus more on outcomes (the ability of IT to produce business value) than means (the harmony between IT and business [[decision-maker]]s within the organizations); for example,
''alignment is the capacity to demonstrate a positive relationship between information technologies and the accepted financial [[measures of performance]].''[http://www.strassmann.com/pubs/alignment/ What is Alignment? Alignment is The Delivery Of The Required Results]
This alignment is in contrast to what is often experienced in organizations: IT and business professionals unable to bridge the gap between themselves because of differences in objectives, culture, and incentives and a mutual ignorance for the other group's [[body of knowledge]]. This rift generally results in expensive IT systems that do not provide adequate [[return on investment]]. For this reason, the search for business-IT alignment is closely associated with attempts to improve the business value of IT investments. Business-IT alignment integrates the information technology to the strategy, mission, and goals of the organization. Key characteristics in order to achieve this alignment are: #The organization must view information technology as an instrument to transform the business. This includes exploring other revenue streams and integrating other facets of their business into each other. For example, using one central [[data warehouse]] to combine two separate, but partnering businesses. #An organization must hold customer service, both externally and internally, at the utmost importance. Communication between the organization and their customers must not be lost. #An organization must rotate both IT and business professionals across different departments and job functions. They must have the knowledge and experience of both sides of the business so that understanding and communication is achieved. Once those three characteristics are achieved, #An organization must provide clear and specific goals to both the IT and business employees. This will create the integration of both entities to achieve a common goal. #Ensure that IT and business employees understand how the company makes or loses money. This is important so that money is not carelessly poured into the IT department and there is no return on that investment. #Organizations must create a vibrant and inclusive [[company culture]]. There must not only be informational unity, but a company as whole. It is not unusual for business and IT professionals within an organization to experience conflict and in-fighting as lack of mutual understanding and the failure to produce desired results leads to blaming and mistrust. The search for B/I alignment often includes efforts to establish trust between these two groups and a mechanism for consensus [[decision-making]]. == B/I alignment and IT governance == To achieve B/I alignment, organizations must make better decisions that take into account both business and IT disciplines. Establishing processes for decision-making and control is essentially what is meant by the term "governance"; so B/I alignment is closely related to [[information technology governance]]. A commonly cited definition by IT Governance Institute is:
''IT governance is the responsibility of the board of directors and executive management. It is an integral part of enterprise governance and consists of the leadership and organisational structures and processes that ensure that the organisation’s IT sustains and extends the organization’s strategies and objectives''.[http://www.sohanroy.com/]
Also related to the effort for better decision-making, and therefore often part of B/I alignment - is the area of [[IT portfolio management]], which has to do with decisions about which IT projects are funded and which are not. == B/I alignment and business transformation == Ultimately, value must come not just from the IT tools that are selected, but also in the way that they are used in the organization. For this reason, the scope of B/I alignment also includes business transformation, in which organizations redesign how work is accomplished in order to realize efficiencies made possible by new IT. Thus, implementing IT to achieve its full potential for business value includes not only a technical component, but also an organizational [[change management]] component (see the Risk3 model below). It is important to consider the overall value chain in technology development projects as the challenge for the value creation is increasing with the growing competitiveness between organizations that has become evident ([https://web.archive.org/web/20101014034657/http://harvardbookstore.biz/ Bird, 2010]). The concept of value creation through technology is heavily dependent upon the alignment of technology and business strategies. While the value creation for an organization is a network of relationships between internal and external environments, technology plays an important role in improving the overall value chain of an organization. However, this increase requires business and technology management to work as a creative, synergistic, and collaborative team instead of a purely mechanistic span of control. Technology can help the organization recognize improved competitive advantage within the industry it resides and generate superior performance at a greater value, [https://web.archive.org/web/20101014034657/http://harvardbookstore.biz/] according to Bird ( Bird, M. (2010). Modern Management Guide to Information Technology. Create Space. {{cite web |url=http://harvardbookstore.biz |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-08-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101014034657/http://harvardbookstore.biz/ |archivedate=2010-10-14 |df= }}). == Alignment models == Henderson & Venkatraman can be seen as the founding fathers of business/IT alignment and published an article called ''Strategic Alignment: Leveraging Information Technology for transforming organisations - IBM Systems Journal, vol32, NO1''. Typical [[Enterprise architecture framework|EA Frameworks]] are used to achieve business-IT alignment, as these frameworks links business and technology layers of organization over common threads. [[The Open Group Architecture Framework|TOGAF]] is a framework by Open Group which defines a very strong method of developing the enterprise architecture. The method is called ADM (architecture development method) [[Zachman Framework|Zachman EA framework]] is developed by John Zachman and it defines which artifacts enterprises need to develop to be able to organize themselves better. It is also widely accepted framework in the industry. In the Risk3[http://changethebusiness.com/wp-content/uploads/2011/03/risk3.pdf Risk3 Assessment - Are You Managing the Three Risks that Threaten Your IT Implementation? (-- needs a paiement)]{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} model, the objective of B/I alignment is to manage three separate risks associated with IT projects: technical risk (will the system function as it should?), organizational risk (will individuals within the organization use the system as they should?), and business risk (will the implementation and adoption of the system translate into business value?). Business value is jeopardized unless all three risks are managed successfully. == See also == * [[Business/IT Fusion|Business IT fusion]]: a concept invented by Omar A. El Sawy in his paper "El Sawy, O.A. (2003) 'The IS Core - IX The 3 Faces of IS Identity: Connection, Immersion, and Fusion' ''Communications of the AIS'', 12, pp. 588-598. * [[Van Grembergen, W.]], and S. De Haes, ''Enterprise Governance of IT: Achieving Strategic Alignment and Value'', Springer, 2009. * [[Van Grembergen, W.]], and S. De Haes, “A Research Journey into Enterprise Governance of IT, Business/IT Alignment and Value Creation”, ''International Journal of IT/Business Alignment and Governance'', Vol. No. 1, 2010, pp. 1–13. * S. De Haes, and [[Wim Van Grembergen]], “An Exploratory Study into the Design of an IT Governance Minimum Baseline through Delphi Research”, ''Communications of AIS'', No. 22, 2008, pp. 443–458. * S. De Haes, and [[Wim Van Grembergen]], “An Exploratory Study into IT Governance Implementations and its Impact on Business/IT Alignment”, ''Information Systems Management'', Vol. 26, 2009, pp. 123–137. * S. De Haes, and [[Wim Van Grembergen]], “Exploring the relationship between IT governance practices and business/IT alignment through extreme case analysis in Belgian mid-to-large size financial enterprises”, ''Journal of Enterprise Information Management'', Vol. 22, No. 5, 2009, pp. 615–637. * [[service-oriented modeling#Service-oriented modeling framework|Service-oriented modeling framework (SOMF)]], provides a framework for business and IT alignment through transformation of business services into solution services == References == {{reflist}} == External links == * [https://web.archive.org/web/20050605082349/http://www.itgi.org/ The IT Governance Institute] * [http://www.research.ibm.com/journal/sj/382/henderson.pdf Strategic Alignment: Leveraging Information Technology for transforming organisations - IBM Systems Journal, vol32, NO1](-- broken URL) * [http://www.strassmann.com/pubs/alignment Paul Strassman] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110823171514/http://oneprofessor.com/tosa/ Total Organizational Strategic Alliance Certifications] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20071216000440/http://harvardbusinessonline.hbsp.harvard.edu/b01/en/common/item_detail.jhtml Weill and Ross on IT governance] * [http://www.ictstandard.org ICT Standard for Management] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110724061501/http://www.antwerpmanagementschool.be/kennis_onderzoek/kennis_expertisecentra/itag_research_institute Information Technology Alignment and Governance (ITAG) Research Institute] (-- broken URL) {{DEFAULTSORT:Business It Alignment}} [[Category:Business terms]]

'''Business acquisition''' is the process of acquiring a [[company]] to build on strengths or weaknesses of the acquiring company. A [[merger]] is similar to an acquisition but refers more strictly to combining all of the interests of both companies into a stronger single company. The end result is to grow the business in a quicker and more profitable manner than normal organic growth would allow.
==Process== The process begins with defining the type of [[business]] that would make a good acquisition. Generally businesses within the same segment or a highly complementary market segment are targeted. Once defined the target business is approached and if interest is shown [[due diligence]] is performed to ascertain the financial and other conditions of the business.
When the financial terms are agreed upon, and the contract is signed the merger portion of the acquisition begins. Overlapping processes, personnel and products are evaluated and the better-performing pieces are retained.
==Single business acquisitions and split and sell== A single acquisition refers to one company buying the assets and operations of another company and absorbing what is needed while simply discarding duplicated or unnecessary pieces of the acquired business. "Split and sell" acquisitions involve buying an entire business in order to gain one or two pieces of the business. The acquiring business may wish to retain the customer list and a product line, while moving manufacturing and other production related duties to an existing line. In this case the excess is often sold off to recapture some of the acquisition cost.
==Affiliate acquisitions== Businesses that use affiliates to sell and market their products may find themselves in the position of losing control of the marketing portion. This presents a danger as the entire [[business cycle]] is dependent on the [[sales cycle]], which is now external to the business. In this scenario the acquiring business may be forced into paying a premium to the affiliate, to regain control of the process without upsetting current customers and cash flow. In rare instances the [[affiliate (commerce)|affiliate]] will gain so much influence that it can purchase the parent company.
== Risks == There are many risks related to business acquisition and a number of mergers or acquisition fail ending up inducing higher operating costs. There are a set of criteria that are usually followed to know if a business is a good target for acquisition such as : having operative processes, a profitable and documented customer acquisition strategy, good profits, a good customer retention strategy, etc.

[[File:SPOO Graf.jpg|thumb|316x316px|Caspar Mathias Spoo's grave in Esch-sur-Alzette]] '''Caspar Mathias Spoo''' (7 January 1837 – 17 March 1914) was a Luxembourgish industrialist and politician.
Spoo was born in [[Echternach]] in 1837. His parents were workers in the earthenware factory, and died early. He joined the civil service from a young age, to make a living for himself and his siblings. He gave up his position in the postal service in order to open the ''Société Duchscher Frères et Spoo'' with André Duchscher, his old friend.<ref name=industrie>[http://www.industrie.lu/spooesch.html "Maschinenfabrik Spoo & Co., Esch/Alzette"] industrie.lu</ref> From 1886, he worked for two years as an accountant at the [[Dudelange]] foundry; he then struck out on his own in 1888 to open an ironmongery in [[Esch-Alzette]] with a workshop constructing ovens, cauldrons, etc.: the ''Maschinenfabrik Spoo & Co''.
Additionally, he was politically active. He was elected to the communal council of Esch in 1893 and to the [[Chamber of Deputies (Luxembourg)|Chamber of Deputies]] in 1896.<ref name=industrie /> Along with [[Michel Welter]], he was one of the first people to engage in modern election campaigning in Luxembourg, by drafting and publishing a manifesto and giving speeches. Politically, he belonged to the left-liberal middle-class. Influenced by André Duchscher, he campaigned for [[universal suffrage]], progressive taxation and social security. He also called for the construction of an industrial school and a secondary school for girls in Esch, and demanded that the [[Esch-sur-Alzette (canton)|canton of Esch]], whose economic and demographic importance had increased due to industrialisation, should receive more seats in the Chamber. His social campaigning, in the [[paternalistic]] tradition of the 19th century, earned him the nickname "Pappa Spoo".
He was married to Barbe Kiesel, and was the father of Armand Spoo. At his funeral in Esch, Michel Welter gave a eulogy, calling Spoo the "conscience of Luxembourgish socialism."<ref>Muller, P.J. ''Tatsachen aus der Geschichte des Luxemburger Landes'', 1968. p. 339</ref>
==Luxembourgish language==
At his maiden speech in the Chamber on 9 December 1896, Spoo spoke in Luxembourgish, and demanded that Luxembourgish should be allowed in the Chamber.<ref>Speech in full in: Hoffmann, Fernand. ''Geschichte der Luxemburger Mundartdichtung, Bd. 1''. Luxembourg, 1964.</ref> His justification was the following: he argued that Luxembourgish was covered by Article 29 of the Constitution of 1868, which defined the official languages as German and French, and Luxembourgish was, after all, German — and indeed older and more venerable than so-called [[High German]]. He described it as one of the richest and healthiest idioms of the Germanic tongue, containing a treasure trove full of valuable language gems and words. The Chamber of Deputies voted on the question, whether Luxembourgish could be spoken in its sessions, and Spoo's proposition was almost unanimously rejected.
Spoo was not the first one to speak Luxembourgish in a Chamber session: on 28 April 1848 in [[Ettelbrück]], while it was being debated if Luxembourg should participate in the [[Frankfurt Parliament]], Karl Mathias André changed in mid-speech from French to Luxembourgish, and received a reply from [[Norbert Metz]] in Luxembourgish, as "the public should understand everything." These were the first Luxembourgish words spoken in the Chamber.
When the [[Education Law of 1912]] was being drafted, Spoo demanded that Luxembourgish should be an obligatory subject in primary schools, and was successful. He was supported in this by the prime minister [[Paul Eyschen]], and [[Nik Welter]] was tasked with writing the textbook ''Das Luxemburgische und sein Schrifttum''.
Spoo also wrote diverse articles on [[Michel Lentz]] and [[Dicks (writer)|Dicks]] in ''Ons Hémecht'' and the ''Natio'n'', and worked around the country to bring [[Michel Rodange]]'s satirical epic ''[[Rénert the Fox]]'', which had remained obscure until then, to a wider audience.

Spoo & M. Welter: 100 Joer sozialistesch Deputéiert. 1896-1996.'' Séance académique du 18 juin 1996 à l'Hôtel de Ville d'Esch-sur-Alzette. | order3 = Member of Hong Kong | office3 = Election Committee | term_start3 = 2017 | term_end3 = }} }} '''Daryl Ng Win Kong''' <small>[[Justice of the peace|JP]]</small> (born in 1978), is a businessman <ref>http://the-sun.on.cc/cnt/news/20150822/00408_005.html</ref> and company director based in Hong Kong. He is the eldest son of [[Robert Ng]], chairman of [[Sino Group]] and its subsidiaries. Daryl is deputy chairman of Sino Group,<ref>https://www.sino.com/en-US/About-Us/Management-Profile/Sino-Land-Company-Limited</ref> which comprises [[Sino Land]],<ref>http://www.sino.com/en-US/About-Us/Management-Profile/Sino-Land-Company-Limited</ref> [[Sino Hotels]]<ref>http://www.sino.com/en-US/About-Us/Management-Profile/Sino-Hotels-(Holdings)-Limited</ref> and [[Tsim Sha Tsui Properties]].<ref>http://www.sino.com/en-US/About-Us/Management-Profile/Tsim-Sha-Tsui-Properties-Limited</ref>
==Early life== Daryl Ng was born at [[Queen Mary Hospital (Hong Kong)|Queen Mary Hospital]],{{citation needed|date=October 2017}} in [[Hong Kong]] and attended the [[Diocesan Boys' School]] in his youth.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://orientaldaily.on.cc/cnt/news/20131001/00176_089.html|script-title=zh:再做爸爸 黃永光數口差|trans-title=Dad again Ng Win Kong is bad in counting number|date=1 October 2013|access-date=15 October 2017|department=column {{lang|zh|中環出更}}|work=Oriental Daily News|publication-place=Hong Kong|publisher=Oriental Press Group|language=zh-hk}}</ref> He later studied in the United States, and graduated from [[Columbia University]] in 2001.<ref name=etnet>{{cite news|url=http://www.etnet.com.hk/www/tc/news/topic_news_detail.php?category=special&newsid=4248|script-title=zh:富豪之後(四): 信置黃永光 落手落腳累積班底|trans-title=Descendant of billionaire (4): Sino Group Ng Win Kong Do-It-Himself to build his own team|date=24 June 2005|access-date=16 October 2017|language=zh-hk|website=etnet.com.hk|publication-place=Hong Kong|publisher=Hong Kong Economic Times Holdings}}</ref>
==Business career== After graduation from university, Daryl Ng joined [[Sino Group]], founded by his late grandfather.<ref name=etnet/>
In addition to day-to-day operations of Sino Group, Daryl Ng took charge of the Old Tai O Police Station project, which was converted to a nine-room boutique hotel, Tai O Heritage Hotel under Batch I of the Revitalising Historic Buildings Through Partnership Scheme of the Development Bureau. He told ''[[The New York Times]]'' that he hoped the project “..achieves three aspects: to allow visitors to experience the delights and charms of a local Hong Kong village, to appreciate the heritage and history of Hong Kong, as well as eco-tourism.”<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/11/28/travel/in-hong-kong-history-at-a-new-hotel.html|title=In Hong Kong, History at a New Hotel|date=27 November 2012|access-date=15 October 2017|work=The New York Times|first=Alex F.|last=McMillan|location=Hong Kong|publication-place=New York City}}</ref>
He is also responsible for [[The Fullerton Heritage]] project in Singapore. The waterfront precinct comprises four historic buildings and three modern architecture; it has received a number of awards in heritage conservation and hospitality.<ref name=etnet/>
==Public services== Daryl Ng also serves on the board of some public organisations, such as the M+ Board of the M+ Museum of the [[West Kowloon Cultural District]], Hong Kong.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.westkowloon.hk/en/the-authority/m-board/m-acquisitions-committee/people/mr-daryl-ng-win-kong-jp-mr-daryl-ng-win-kong-jp/|title=Mr Daryl NG Win-kong, JP|access-date=15 October 2017|publisher=West Kowloon Cultural District}}</ref> The board is responsible for formulating the vision and mission, as well as the strategies, policies and guidelines in relation to museological matters and professional standards of operations for the museum.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.westkowloon.hk/en/the-authority/m-board|title=M+ Board|access-date=15 October 2017|publisher=West Kowloon Cultural District}}</ref> He also serves as a board member of the National Heritage Board, Singapore.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nhb.gov.sg/about-us/management|title=Management|publisher=National Heritage Board|publication-place=Singapore|access-date=16 October 2017}}</ref>
===Political career=== Daryl Ng is the member of the 12th Beijing Committee of the [[Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference]] ({{zh|s=第十二届北京市政协}}, 2013 to 2018); at the 10th Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference (2003 to 2008), Daryl Ng was a member of the Sichuan Committee.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bjzx.gov.cn/zjwy/ljwy/201612/t20161214_446.html|script-title=zh:中国人民政治协商会议北京市第十二届委员会委员名单|trans-title=List of members of the 12th Beijing Committee of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference|access-date=16 October 2017|publisher=Beijing Committee of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference|language=zh-cn}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://dzb.scdaily.cn/2007/12/28/20071228721444442473.htm|script-title=zh:中国人民政治协商会议第十届四川省委员会委员名单|trans-title=List of members of the 10th Sichuan Committee of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference|date=28 December 2007|newspaper={{lang|zh|四川日报}} [Sichuan Daily News]|publication-place=Chengdu|access-date=16 October 2017|language=Chinese}}</ref>
In Hong Kong, Daryl Ng is a member of the [[List of members of the Election Committee of Hong Kong, 2017–22|Election Committee (2017–2022)]].

[[Ronald Reagan UCLA Medical Center]] |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |budget = |website = {{URL|doheny.org}} |remarks = }} '''Doheny Eye Institute''' ('''Doheny Eye''' or '''DEI''') established in 1947,{{cite web|title=Estelle Doheny’s loss of sight gave rise to a different kind of vision|url=https://news.usc.edu/11069/Estelle-Doheny-s-loss-of-sight-gave-rise-to-a-different-kind-of-vision/|website=news.usc.edu|publisher=USC}} is a nonprofit ophthalmic [[research institute]]. The doctors and scientists of Doheny Eye Institute undertake basic and clinical research, a role known as a [[physician-scientist]]. ==History== [[File:Carrie_painting.jpg|thumbnail|left|Painting of Carrie Estelle Doheny.|175px]] In 1944, Carrie Estelle Doheny, wife of the prominent Los Angeles oilman [[Edward L. Doheny]], became blind in her left eye and began to suffer a progressive loss of sight in her right eye.{{cite web|title=Stein Eye Institute and Doheny Eye Institute Join Forces to Improve Patient Access to Top Vision Specialists|url=http://www.newswise.com/articles/stein-eye-institute-and-doheny-eye-institute-join-forces-to-improve-patient-access-to-top-vision-specialists|website=News Wise}} The loss of vision inspired her to create and fund the organization named for her, the [[Estelle Doheny Eye Foundation]], in 1947.{{cite web|title=Carrie Estelle Doheny Foundation: Los Angeles Grants|url=http://www.insidephilanthropy.com/fundraising-los-angeles-grants/carrie-estelle-doheny-foundation-los-angeles-grants.html?SSScrollPosition=700|website=Inside Philanthropy}}{{cite web|title=About the Foundation|url=http://www.dohenyfoundation.org/about/about-the-foundation/|website=Carrie Estelle Doheny Foundation}} The foundation was formed with the purpose of supporting “the conservation, improvement and restoration” of human eyesight. The Doheny Pavilion, at [[St. Vincent Medical Center (Los Angeles)|St. Vincent Medical Center]] in Los Angeles, opened to patients in 1956. Drs. A. Ray Irvine, Sr., and [[S. Rodman Irvine]] served as co-Medical Directors.{{cite web|last1=Rao|first1=Narsing|title=Alexander Ray Irvine, Jr, MD|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1312084/pdf/taos00005-0043.pdf|website=National Institute of Health}} Dr. A. Ray Irvine, Sr., served as the personal ophthalmologist of Carrie Estelle Doheny, as well of American entrepreneur [[Walt Disney]].{{cite web|title=Alexander R. Irvine, MD|url=http://findingmickey.squarespace.com/disneyland-windows/single-gallery/2972732|}}{{cite web|title=Baby Care Center|url=http://disney-pal.com/Disneyland/baby_care_center2.htm|}} In 1966, USC invited the Estelle Doheny Eye Foundation Trustees to inspect an available parcel on the USC Health Sciences Campus, and negotiations to acquire the property began. In 1971, the Estelle Doheny Eye Foundation finalized its formal affiliation agreement with USC, and named William H. Spencer, MD, as its new Medical Director, forming what was then called the "Doheny Eye Institute", known since 2013 as the [[USC Eye Institute]].{{cite web|title=The Courier-Journal|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/110135621/|website=Newspapers}} In 1977, Stephen J. Ryan became Medical Director and proposed the creation of the Doheny Eye Hospital, to serve as a new headquarters and provide clinical facilities for the ophthalmology faculty. The hospital was officially dedicated in 1985.{{cite web|title=$7.5-Million Doheny Eye Hospital to Be Dedicated|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1985-03-17/realestate/re-35605_1_facility|publisher=Los Angeles Times}}{{cite web|title=Keck School Dean Stephen J. Ryan to step down|url=https://news.usc.edu/54/keck-school-of-medicine-dean-stephen-j-ryan-to-step-down-in-june/|website=USC News|publisher=USC}} In 1987, the Estelle Doheny Eye Foundation was renamed the Doheny Eye Institute, and a $32 million campaign was launched to build the Doheny Eye Institute building.{{cite web|title=Debs Hear Message of Inspiration From Cardinal-Elect|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1991-06-06/news/vw-408_1_patrick-doheny|publisher=Los Angeles Times}} Shortly thereafter, Stephen J. Ryan became President of the institute.{{cite web|title=Stephen J. Ryan dies at 73; longtime dean of USC medical school|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2013/may/05/local/la-me-stephen-ryan-20130506|publisher=Los Angeles Times}} In 1992, TV personality [[Gene Autry]] was honored as the first recipient of the institute's Doheny Award.{{cite book|last1=Cusic|first1=Don|title=Gene Autry: His Life and Career|page=186|url=https://books.google.com/books/about/Gene_Autry.html?id=4aH9gzma0gwC}}{{cite web|title=Doheny Eye Institute Rustles Up Honors for a Favorite Cowboy|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1992-01-16/news/vw-112_1_doheny-eye-institute|publisher=Los Angeles Times}} The Doheny Retina Institute was established in 2001,{{cite web|last1=Weiner|first1=Jon|title=USC Ophthalmologists Announce Launch of Permanent Retinal Implant Study|url=https://news.usc.edu/3155/USC-Ophthalmologists-Announce-Launch-of-Permanent-Retinal-Implant-Study/|website=USC News|publisher=USC}} followed by the Doheny Image Reading Center (DIRC) in 2003.{{cite web|title=About Us|url=http://dirc.doheny.org/about/|website=Doheny Image Reading Center}} In 2011, USC and the Doheny Eye Institute fell into a dispute over renovations, permits, and other matters related to the building, which led to litigation.Alex Ortolani For Law360. October 28, 2011 [http://www.law360.com/articles/281559/usc-focuses-ire-on-eye-institute-over-lease-permits USC Focuses Ire On Eye Institute Over Lease Permits] Doheny and USC ended their relationship, and USC created a new entity called the USC Eye Institute for its department of ophthalmology.{{cite web|url= https://news.usc.edu/57287/humayun-named-first-director-of-usc-eye-institute/ |title= International expert in eye diseases returns to Keck School|publisher=''USC News''|date=2014-11-14|accessdate=2015-01-07}} In December 2013 the Doheny Eye Institute entered into an exclusive, long-term affiliation agreement with the [[University of California Los Angeles]],{{cite web|last1=Schmidt|first1=Elaine|title=Jules Stein Eye Institute at UCLA and Doheny Eye Institute pursue long-term affiliation|url=http://newsroom.ucla.edu/releases/jules-stein-eye-institute-at-ucla-247636|publisher=UCLA News|accessdate=29 July 2013}} forming the "Doheny Eye Center UCLA". Ronald E. Smith had served as Chairman of Ophalmology at USC from 1995 to 2013,{{cite web|url= http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/fredericknewspost/obituary.aspx?pid=170284404 |title= Dr. Ronald E. Smith |publisher=The Frederick News Post|date=2014-03-17|accessdate=2015-01-07}} and left USC to follow Doheny, and became vice chair of the department at UCLA.{{cite journal|title=Letter from the Chair|journal=Eye - Stein Eye Institutes, UCLA|date=Spring 2014 |volume=32 |issue=2|page=2 |url=http://www.jsei.org/About/PDF/EYESpring2014.pdf}} ==Awards and rankings== ===Grants=== By 1986 the institute ranked 4th in National Eye Institute support, behind research organizations [[Harvard]], [[Johns Hopkins]] and [[Columbia University]].{{citation needed|date=September 2016}} Cumulative Awards from the National Eye Institute exceeded $44 million in 2015.{{cite web|title=Research Portfolio Online Reporting Tools|url=https://projectreporter.nih.gov/Reporter_Viewsh.cfm?sl=12E9CD0F4B85C4D77598B8961CAA4A01A2FFCEB861BF|publisher=National Institute of Health}} ===Rankings=== Doheny Eye Institute has been ranked in the Top Ten by ''[[U.S. News & World Report]]'' and in the Top Ten by ''[[American Academy of Ophthalmology]]'' since rankings began in 1993 and 1996, respectively.{{citation needed|date=September 2016}} In 2016, Stein and Doheny Eye Institutes were ranked among the top 5 ophthalmology institutes in the United States by ''[[U.S. News & World Report]]''.{{cite news|title=Stein and Doheny Eye Institutes earn top spot in US News ranking|url=http://health.usnews.com/best-hospitals/area/ca/ucla-medical-center-6931755/ophthalmology}} ==See also== *[[American Academy of Ophthalmology]] *[[David Geffen School of Medicine at UCLA]] *[[Jules Stein Eye Institute]] *[[National Eye Institute]] *[[USC Eye Institute]] ==References== {{Reflist|33em}} [[Category:Eye care in the United States]] [[Category:University of California, Los Angeles]] [[Category:Medical research institutes in the United States]] [[Category:Medical and health organizations based in California]] [[Category:Academic health science centres]] [[Category:Life sciences industry]] [[Category:1947 establishments in California]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1947]]

{{short description|21st-century Italian designer and artist}} {{Infobox nobility | name = Domitilla Harding | image = | caption = | title = | full name = | birth_date = | birth_place = [[Rome, Italy]] | father = John Harding | mother = Lavinia Lante della Rovere | spouse = [[Mark Getty]] (1982–2011, divorced) | issue = Joseph Getty
Alexander Getty
Julius Getty | noble family = [[House of della Rovere|della Rovere]] | education = | occupation = designer, artist }} '''Domitilla Harding''' (formerly '''Getty''') is an Italian designer and artist. == Early life == Domitilla Harding was born and raised in Rome. She is the daughter of John Harding and Lavinia Lante della Rovere.{{cite book|title=All the Money in the World: previously published as Painfully Rich|author=Pearson, J.|date=2011|publisher=Bloomsbury Publishing|isbn=9781448207817|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=KTmDpm7hRUkC&pg=PT206|accessdate=2018-01-07}}{{cite book|title=Tout l'argent du monde: le livre du nouveau film événement de Ridley Scott|author=Pearson, J.|date=2018|publisher=HarperCollins|isbn=9791033902201|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=J_1BDwAAQBAJ&pg=PT201|accessdate=2018-01-25}} Her mother is a member of the [[House of della Rovere]], an Italian noble family with ties to the papacy.{{cite web|url=https://www.wmagazine.com/gallery/home-gettys-tuscany/all|author=W Magazine|title=Mark and Domitilla Getty's Tuscan villa Photos|website=W Magazine|accessdate=2018-01-07}}{{cite web|url=http://www.townandcountrymag.com/leisure/sporting/a6813/palio-horse-race-getty-family/|title=Palio Horse Race in Sienna Italy — Getty Family Involvement in Palio Horse Race|website=townandcountrymag.com|accessdate=2018-01-07}}{{cite web|url=https://www.vogue.com/article/sabine-ghanem-joseph-getty-wedding-rome-italy|title=Roman Holiday: Sabine Ghanem's Wedding to Joseph Getty|website=Vogue|accessdate=2018-01-07}} == Career == Harding has worked as a furniture designer and as a designer behind the Miss Italy fashion label.{{cite web|url=https://mobile.nytimes.com/slideshow/100000004641410/2016/09/13/t-magazine/design/interiors-books-rizzoli/s/12tmag-books-slide-AMP2.html|title="Domus: A Journey Into Italy’s Most Creative Interiors"|website=NYTimes.com|accessdate=2018-01-07}}{{cite web|url=http://www.tatler.com/gallery/meet-the-getty-family-andrew-getty-history-fortune-getty-images|title=Meet the Gettys! - Getty family history and fortune — Getty Images | Tatler Magazine|website=tatler.com|accessdate=2018-01-07}} The Miss Italy label began as a collection of swimwear for The Cross in west London, in which Harding used recycled fabrics and old textile techniques practiced by traditional Italian artisans and later developed into a fashion brand mixing vintage and modern designs.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/theobserver/2000/oct/01/features.magazine27|title=Interiors: Wonder walls | From the Observer|website=The Guardian|accessdate=2018-01-07}} Harding works as a glass sculptor with glass master Andrea Zilio at the [[Anfora]] foundry in [[Murano]], creating glass vessels, vases, and sculptures.{{cite web|url=https://www.vogue.com/article/sabine-getty-holiday-christmas-party-london|title=Sabine Getty Hosts a Christmas Jumper Party at Her Home in London|website=Vogue|accessdate=2018-01-07}}{{cite book|title=Maiolica: Italian Renaissance Ceramics in the Metropolitan Museum of Art: |author1=Wilson, T.|author2=Syson, L.|date=2016|publisher=Metropolitan Museum of Art|isbn=9781588395610|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=2i_ADAAAQBAJ&pg=PA37|page=37|accessdate=2018-01-07}}{{cite web|url=http://scott-andco.com/gianluca-longo-presents-vases-and-vessels-at-david-gill-gallery/|title=Gianluca Longo presents Vases and Vessels at David Gill Gallery | Scott & Co|website=scott-andco.com|accessdate=2018-01-07}}{{cite web|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/art-and-culture/heading-to-venice-don-t-miss-the-first-international-festival-that-celebrates-glass-making/story-AtibkXKBc23rE7gpp0iEEN.html|title=Heading to Venice? Don’t miss the first international festival that celebrates glass making | art and culture|website=Hindustan Times|accessdate=2018-01-07}} Her work has been showcased in various museums, shops, and galleries.http://www.bonomogallery.com/gab/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/Press-Release-Wood-Glass-Paper.pdf{{cite web|url=https://www.cntraveler.com/stories/2015-05-05/venice-biennale-2015-what-to-do-besides-art-hop|title=Venice Biennale 2015: What to Do Besides Art Hop — Condé Nast Traveler|website=cntraveler.com|accessdate=2018-01-07}} In 2013, Harding's work was shown in the Wood Glass Paper exhibition at the Alessandra Bonomo Gallery in Rome. In 2015 she exhibited nine glass sculptures at the Arte Del Vetro Oggi In Italia at Vulla Necchi Campiglio in Milan, sponsored by [[Fondo Ambiente Italiano]]. Her work has also been shown at Marie Rose Kahane's studio Yali, Villa Dei Vescovi, Murano Oggi, Emozione di Vetro, and the [[Fondazione Musei Civici di Venezia]].{{cite web|url=http://www.theveniceglassweek.com/tvgw/events/domitilla-harding-vasi-e-bottiglioni/?lang=en|title=Domitilla Harding – "Vases and Bottles"|website=theveniceglassweek.com|accessdate=2018-01-07}}{{cite web|url=http://domitillaharding.com/bio/|title=Bio|website=Domitilla Harding|accessdate=2018-01-07}} == Personal life == Harding married [[Mark Getty]], grandson of [[J. Paul Getty]] and heir to the [[Getty family]], in 1982 at the [[Santi Apostoli, Rome|Basilica of the Twelve Apostles]] in Rome. They have three sons: Joseph, Alexander, and Julius.{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/music/opera/8544237/Garsington-Opera-Behind-the-Getty-gates.html|title=Garsington Opera: Behind the Getty gates|website=Telegraph|accessdate=2018-01-07}} In 1985, the couple purchased an abandoned village near [[Orgia]] and began restoring it.{{cite web|url=https://inews.co.uk/news/long-reads/mark-getty-all-the-money-in-the-world/|website=inews.co.uk|title=How Mark Getty grew from the child seen in 'All The Money In The World' to be one of Britain's richest men|accessdate=2018-01-07}} Harding and Getty separated in 2010 and divorced in 2011.{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/mandrake/10093175/Lambton-sisters-find-a-powerful-ally-in-Getty.html|title=Lambton sisters find a powerful ally in Getty|website=Telegraph|accessdate=2018-01-07}} After their divorce, Harding relocated from their home at [[Wormsley Park]] to [[Tuscany]].{{cite book|title=Body — Language — Communication|author=Gruyter, D.|date=2014|volume=2|publisher=De Gruyter|isbn=9783110302028|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=QAGTBgAAQBAJ&pg=PA1252|page=1252|accessdate=2018-01-07}} == References == {{reflist}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Harding, Domitilla}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:21st-century Italian sculptors]] [[Category:Artists from Rome]] [[Category:Getty family]] [[Category:Glass makers]] [[Category:House of della Rovere]] [[Category:Italian untitled nobility]] [[Category:Italian fashion designers]] [[Category:Italian furniture designers]] [[Category:Italian women sculptors]] [[Category:Italian Roman Catholics]]

{{for|the South African footballer|Jerome McCarthy}} {{Infobox academic | name = Edmund Jerome McCarthy | othernames = E. Jerome McCarthy, Jerry McCarthy | birth_date = {{birth date|1928|02|20}} | birth_place = | death_date = {{death date and age|2015|12|03|1928|02|20}} | death_place = [[Michigan]] | nationality = American | occupation = Professor, author, consultant | spouse = Joanne McCarthy | discipline = [[Marketing]] | education = {{plain list | * B. Sc, [[Northwestern University]], 1950 * MA, [[University of Minnesota]], 1954 * PhD, University of Minnesota, 1958}} | thesis_title = An Analysis of the Use of Marketing Research in Product Development, 1958 | alma_mater = Northwestern University, University of Minnesota | workplaces = [[Harvard Business School]], [[University of Notre Dame]], [[Michigan State University]], [[University of Oregon]] | notable_works = ''Basic Marketing: A Managerial Approach'' (1960) | notable_ideas = [[Marketing mix|The 4 Ps]] }}
'''Edmund Jerome McCarthy''' (February 20, 1928 – December 3, 2015) was an American [[marketing]] professor and author. He proposed the concept of the [[Marketing mix|4 Ps marketing mix]] in his 1960 book ''Basic Marketing: A Managerial Approach'', which has been one of the top textbooks in university marketing courses since its publication.<ref name="Milestones">{{cite journal | title=Milestones in Marketing | journal=Business History Review | url=http://www.hbs.edu/faculty/Publication%20Files/Milestones%20in%20Marketing_Quelch_Jocz_cca1547e-d4e1-4470-8f92-edc877bebaf7.pdf|volume=82 |date=Winter 2008 | pages=827–838 | publisher= The President and Fellows of Harvard College | author1=[[John Quelch|John A. Quelch]] | author2=Katherine E. Jocz | website= | doi=10.1017/S0007680500063236 }}</ref><ref name="Sales Management" /> According to the ''Oxford Dictionary of Marketing'', McCarthy was a "pivotal figure in the development of marketing thinking".<ref name="Oxford">{{cite web | title=Edmund Jerome McCarthy | website=Oxford Reference, Oxford University Press | url=http://www.oxfordreference.com/view/10.1093/oi/authority.20110803100143321 | accessdate=November 4, 2016 }}</ref> He was also a founder, advisory board member, and consultant for Planned Innovation Institute, which was established to bolster Michigan industry. In 1987, McCarthy received the [[American Marketing Association]]'s Trailblazer Award, and was voted one of the "top five" leaders in marketing thought by the field's educators.
== Education ==
McCarthy received his Bachelor of Science degree in 1950 from [[Northwestern University]]. He received his Master of Arts in 1954<ref name=MA>{{citation | publisher=University of Minnesota | title=List of Graduates (with previous qualifications) | work=Press Releases: June–September, 1954 | date=June 12, 1954 | quote=University of Minnesota Press Release, June – September, 1954. From the publicity director: Listed here you will find the names of persons who previously received degrees from your school who were awarded advanced degrees at commencement exercises at the University of Minnesota June 12, 1954. The degree indicated in parentheses is that received from your school with the date it was given. The degree typed out is the new degree from the University of Minnesota... Edmund Jerome McCarthy (B,S, '50) master of arts.}}</ref> and his PhD in 1958 from the [[University of Minnesota]].<ref name=Obituary>{{ cite news | title=Jerry McCarthy [Obituary] | newspaper=Lansing State Journal | date=December 27, 2015 | url= http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/lsj/obituary.aspx?pid=177015687 | accessdate= }}</ref> His doctoral dissertation was ''An Analysis of the Use of Marketing Research in Product Development''.<ref name="Basic Marketing - Author's notes" />
== Career == ===Early career=== He was a professor of the College of Commerce at the [[University of Notre Dame]],<ref name=PR /><ref name=Scholar /> beginning in 1956, where he taught courses about how statistics and mathematics applied to business problems.<ref name=PR />
In the spring of 1959, while a professor of the College of Commerce, he was informed that he received a one-year [[Ford Foundation]] Fellowship at Harvard Business School and [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]].<ref name=PR>{{citation |url=http://archives.nd.edu/pr/pdf/PR_1959_03.pdf |publisher=University of Notre Dame | title=University of Notre Dame, Department of Public Information (press releases) | author=James B. Murphy, Public Information Director | page=2 | date=March 17, 1959 }}</ref> Beginning in September, he focused on mathematical applications for business, as part of the Foundation's program to "strengthen business education and research",<ref name=Scholar>{{cite journal | url=http://archives.nd.edu/Scholastic/VOL_0100/VOL_0100_ISSUE_0018.pdf | title=News Briefs | page=29 | journal=the Scholastic | publisher= Notre Dame University | date=March 29, 1959 |volume=100|number=18 | accessdate=November 4, 2016 }}</ref><!--- "the Scholastic ---> and specifically to work on [[mathematical model]]s for marketing.
=== Development of the 4Ps === {{main|Marketing mix}}
At the time when McCarthy began his teaching career, the so-called ''functional school of thought'' dominated the discipline. The functional school was primarily concerned with asking questions about what are the functions of marketing, what activities does marketing perform, what is the role of marketing within organisations? Much of the theorising within the functional school focussed on the value adding services performed by intermediaries.<ref>O'Malley, L. and Lichrou, M., "Marketing Theory," in Baker, M.J. and Hart, S., ''The Marketing Book,'' 7th ed., Routledge, Oxon, UK, 2016, pp 37-52</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Weitz|first1=Barton A|last2=Wensley|first2=Robin|title=Handbook of Marketing|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZjQb3xZoVe0C&pg=PA19|date=October 16, 2002|publisher=SAGE|isbn=978-0-85702-530-2|pages=19}}</ref> As the marketing discipline matured, scholars increasingly searched for a more managerial approach that focussed on solving the problems and challenges faced by marketing managers.<ref name="Overview" /><ref name="Constantinides">{{ cite journal | author=E. Constantinides | title=The Marketing Mix Revisited: Towards the 21st Century Marketing | journal=Journal of Marketing Management |volume= 22 | year= 2006 | pages= 407–438| url= http://intranet.fucape.br/uploads/MATERIAIS_AULAS/25112-8.pdf }}</ref> Throughout the 1950s, a number of different approaches to managerial marketing emerged. However, some theorists clung to the functional approach, to the extent that both the functional approach and the managerial approach co-existed for a decade or so.<ref>Sheth, J. N. and Gardner, D.M., ''Marketing Theory: Evolution and Evaluation,'' New York, Wiley, 1988</ref>
The demise of the functional approach has largely been attributed to McCarthy's contribution. According to Hunt and Goolsby, "The publication of McCarthy's ''Basic Marketing'' (1960) is widely cited as the 'beginning of the end' for the functional approach." The 1960s represent a transitional period wherein books adopting the managerial approach existed side by side with those using the more traditional functional approach.<ref>Hunt, Shelby D. and Goolsby, Jerry, "The Rise and Fall of the Functional Approach to Marketing: A Paradigm Displacement Perspective," in Historical Perspectives in Marketing: Essays in Honour of Stanley Hollander, Terence Nevett and Ronald Fullerton (eds), Lexington, MA, Lexington Books, pp 35-37, sdh.ba.ttu.edu/Rise%20and%20Fall%20(88).pdf</ref>
[[File:4Ps.jpg|thumb|McCarthy defined the 4Ps conceptual framework for marketing decision-making, which used [[Product (business)|product]], [[pricing|price]], place (or [[distribution (business)|distribution]]), and [[Promotion (marketing)|promotion]] in the [[marketing mix]].]]
In 1960, McCarthy was the first to propose a marketing mix concept that resonated with both practitioners and academics.<ref name=Dominic /> In his textbook ''Basic Marketing: A Managerial Approach'' (1960), McCarthy defined the 4Ps conceptual framework for marketing decision-making, which used [[Product (business)|product]], [[pricing|price]], place (or [[distribution (business)|distribution]]), and [[Promotion (marketing)|promotion]] in the marketing mix.<ref name="Overview" /><ref name="Constantinides" /> McCarthy organized his text along managerial lines using the four Ps framework. The book's emphasis was on the problems facing the marketing manager, rather than looking at the characteristics of marketing systems and their functions. In addition to chapters devoted to the 4 Ps, the book also included chapters on consumer behaviour, marketing research and market segmentation to round out the tools available to marketers for use in problem-solving.
The managerial approach views marketing as a management science.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Laurent|first1=Gilles|last2=Lilien|first2=Gary L.|last3=Pras|first3=Bernard|title=Research Traditions in Marketing|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PwPsCAAAQBAJ&pg=PA386|date=December 6, 2012|publisher=Springer Science & Business Media|isbn=978-94-011-1402-8|page=386}}</ref> It uses problem-solving to "develop an optimum offering of products, prices, promotion, and place (distribution)," according to the ''Handbook of Marketing.''<ref>{{cite book|last1=Weitz|first1=Barton A|last2=Wensley|first2=Robin|title=Handbook of Marketing|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZjQb3xZoVe0C&pg=PA54|date=October 16, 2002|publisher=SAGE|isbn=978-0-85702-530-2|pages=19, 69}}</ref> A key feature of the managerial approach is that it began to move away from its economics foundations and instead introduced ideas from the new and emerging fields of sociology and psychology, which offered useful insights for explaining aspects of consumer behaviour such as the influence of culture and social class.<ref>Brian Jones, D.G. and Shaw, E.H, "The History of Marketing Thought," in ''Handbook of Marketing,'' Weitz, R. and Wensley, R. (eds), London, UK, 2003, p. 60</ref> It also placed an overt reliance on the quantitative sciences as means of knowing." <ref>Wilkie, W.L. and Moore, E.S., "Macromarketing as a Pillar of Marketing Thought," ''Journal of Macromarketing,'' Vol. 26 No. 2, December 2006, p. 225</ref>
Prior to the publication of McCarthy's text, the concept of a ''marketing mix'' was being debated, however, there was little consensus among marketers about what elements should comprise the marketing mix.<ref>{{ cite journal | author=N.H. Borden | title=The Concept of the Marketing Mix | journal=Journal of Advertising Research | year=1964 | pages=2–7}}</ref><ref>{{citation | author=N.H. Borden | chapter=The Concept of the Marketing Mix |editor=M.J. Baker |title=Marketing: Critical Perspectives on Business and Management | volume=5 | publisher=Routledge | year=2001 | pages= 3–4 | quote=Borden credits his colleague, James Culliton, with the concept of marketers as 'mixers of ingredients' but suggests that he, Borden contributed to the process of popularising the concept }}</ref> They relied on checklists or lengthy classifications of factors that needed to be considered to understand consumer responses.<ref>{{cite journal | author1=W. Waterschoo | author2=C. van den Bulte | title=The 4P Classification of the Marketing Mix Revisited | journal=Journal of Marketing | volume=56 | number=4 | year=1992 | pages=83–93 | jstor= 1251988 }}</ref> Neil H. Borden of the Harvard Business School developed a complicated model in the late 1940s, based upon at least twelve different factors.<ref name="Overview" /> In contrast, McCarthy's concept was a simplifed, memorable set of factors for managerial planning and decision-making.<ref name=Dominic /><ref>{{citation | author=W.A. Cohen | title=The Practical Drucker: Applying the Wisdom of the World's Greatest Management Thinker | publisher=American Management Association | year=2014 | page=139 }}</ref>
McCarthy's marketing mix is based upon four controllable variables that a company manages in its effort to satisfy the corporation's objectives as well as the needs and wants of a [[target market]].<ref name="Overview" /> Once there is understanding of the target market's interests, marketers develop tactics, using the 4Ps, to encourage buyers to purchase product. The successful use of the model is predicated upon the degree to which the target market's needs and wants have been understood, and the extent to when the marketers developed the tactics accordingly.<ref name="Overview" />
McCarthy's 4Ps concept is particularly suited to most consumer products. The model needs modifications for high-end consumer products, in which case relationship management is a factor. Services have some unique marketing issues to be factored into decision-making. Tactics for marketing industrial products should consider elements of long-term contractual agreements.<ref name="Sales Management" /> Regardless of the modifications needed in some cases, the 4Ps remain a generally accepted marketing practice to influence buyers and its concepts still are espoused in contemporary textbooks.<ref name="Milestones" /><ref name="Sales Management">{{cite book|author=Pundrik Mishra|title=Sales Management: Keys to Effective Sales|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7Gpa_kGJASMC&pg=PA34|date=December 1, 2009|publisher=Global India Publications|isbn=978-93-80228-45-7|pages=34–35 }}</ref> Further, the 4Ps marketing mix that McCarthy popularized<ref>{{cite book|author1=Michael R. Czinkota|author2=Ilkka A. Ronkainen|title=International Marketing|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=B7tOpAV3TzEC&pg=PA24|date=June 25, 2013|publisher=Cengage Learning|isbn=1-133-62751-X|page=24}}</ref> has become a foundational and widely adopted marketing framework into the 21st century.<!--- or as of 2009---><ref name=Dominic>{{cite journal | author=G. Dominic |url=http://faculty.mu.edu.sa/public/uploads/1361725683.7557marketing%20mix54.PDF| title=From Marketing Mix to E-Marketing Mix: A Literature Review | journal=International Journal of Business and Management | volume= 9 | number= 4 | year= 2009 | pages=17–24 }}</ref>{{efn|In 1972, Donald C. Marschner, then of the University of New Hampshire, wrote that McCarthy's book "still remains the standard against which all other introductory text-books should be judged."<ref>{{cite journal | author=D.C. Marschner | title=Basic Marketing; A Managerial Approach: Book Review | journal=Journal of Marketing | volume= 36 | number= 1 | date=January 1972 | page=106 | jstor=1250877 }}</ref> [[John Quelch|John A. Quelch]] and Katherine E. Jocz wrote in their "Milestones in Marketing" (2008) article, "Now, the marketing-mix concept is nearly always used in conjunction with the famous 'four Ps' categories... originated by E. Jerome McCarthy.<ref name="Milestones" /> They noted four years later that this book is one of the most widely adopted introductory texts in the history of marketing.<ref>{{cite book | author1=[[John Quelch|John A. Quelch]] | author2=Katherine E. Jocz | title=All Business is Local: Why Place Matters More than Ever in a Global, Virtual World | publisher=Penguin | year=2012 | page=4 }}</ref>}} This is partly due to the simplicity of the model, which makes it adaptable for changes in the marketing area, such as internet commerce.<!---"digital context", "digital technologies", "e-marketing", and "online companies" in the source---> Rather than creating a new model, G. Dominic expressed that McCarthy's 4 Ps could be used with some "extension and adjustment" to develop tactics for the current, ever-changing marketing arena like internet commerce.<ref name=Dominic />
''Basic Marketing: A Managerial Approach'' is one of the world's most popular marketing textbooks. It has been updated by McCarthy and coauthor William D. Perrault more than a dozen times.<ref name="Overview">{{cite book | url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G2-2830600254.html | work=Overview: Marketing Mix: Product, Price, Place, Promotion |date=January 1, 2008 | title=Everyday Finance: Economics, Personal Money Management, and Entrepreneurship }}</ref> The textbook's 19th edition was published in 2013.<ref>{{cite book|author1=William Perreault, Jr.|author2=Joseph Cannon|author3=E. Jerome McCarthy|title=Basic Marketing: 19th Edition|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EXkcAAAAQBAJ|date=January 17, 2013|publisher=McGraw-Hill Higher Education|isbn=978-0-07-751253-8}}</ref>
===Educator and author=== McCarthy had the Ford Foundation Fellowship in 1963 and 1964, when he investigated the role of marketing in [[World economy|global economic development]].<ref name="Basic Marketing - Author's notes" /> After Notre Dame, McCarthy moved to Michigan.<ref name="Murphy p. 93">{{cite book|author1=Patrick E. Murphy|author2=John F. Sherry Jr.|title=Marketing and the Common Good: Essays from Notre Dame on Societal Impact|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nZMqAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA93|date=July 24, 2013|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-134-09107-2|pages=93 |quote=Short bio, Professor Emeritus, research interests - timeless quality of 4Ps, due to ongoing issues }}</ref> He was on the faculty in the Department of Marketing and Supply Chain Management at Michigan State University (MSU).<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.lib.msu.edu/sites/default/files/node/903/edit/FacPubs2015_booklet_web.pdf | title=Stanley C. and Selma D. Hollander Faculty Book Collection, MSU Faculty Publications|website=Michigan State University Libraries | year=2014 | accessdate=November 4, 2016 | page=11}}</ref> In 2013, he was [[Emeritus|Professor Emeritus]] there.<ref>{{cite book|author1=Patrick E. Murphy|author2=John F. Sherry Jr.|title=Marketing and the Common Good: Essays from Notre Dame on Societal Impact|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nZMqAAAAQBAJ&pg=PAxx|date=July 24, 2013|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-134-09107-2|pages=xx}}</ref> During his career, McCarthy also held a position at the University of Oregon.<ref name="Basic Marketing - Author's notes">{{cite book | title=Basic Marketing: A Global Managerial Approach | chapter=Author's biographical notes | edition=11 | location=Canadian | publisher=Irwin | year=2005 | page=v }}</ref>
As an educator, he interested students in marketing and effective marketing strategy planning. He also developed teaching materials for other marketing professors, including "developing and improving marketing texts to reflect the most current thinking in the field".<ref name="Essential" />
He has published books<ref>{{cite web | url=https://catalog.loc.gov/vwebv/search?searchType=7&searchId=10739&maxResultsPerPage=25&recCount=25&recPointer=0&resultPointer=0& | title=Search: E. Jerome McCarthy (returned 48 books) | website=Library of Congress Online Catalog | accessdate=November 6, 2016 }}</ref> and articles in the areas of general marketing, social issues in marketing, and data processing.<ref name="Essential">{{ cite web | title=Essentials of Marketing Information Center: About the Authors | edition=14th | url= http://highered.mheducation.com/sites/0077861043/information_center_view0/about_the_authors.html | publisher= McGraw-Hill Global Education Holdings, LLC | quote=The website is for information about ''Essentials of Marketing: A Marketing Strategy Planning Approach'' (14th edition) by William D. Perreault, Jr., Joseph P. Cannon; and E. Jerome McCarthy. The book's copyright year is 2015.}}</ref>
===Planned Innovation Institute=== McCarthy played a pivotal role in the Planned Innovation Institute as founder, Advisory Board member, and consulting educator.<ref name="PII" /> Planned Innovation Institute was founded to identify causes and create solutions to address "major causes of new product failure in Michigan industry." It modeled its program's concepts after the University of Michigan Institute of Science and Technology research program.<ref name="PII History">{{cite web | title= History | website=Planned Innovation Institute | url=http://plannedinnovationinstitute.com/History.html | accessdate=November 4, 2016 }}</ref>
McCarthy, with Frank R. Bacon, Jr., used the concepts from his ''Basic Marketing'' textbook to develop the institute's Product-Market Analysis component that first focused on new product innovation and then business retention strategies.<ref name="PII History" /> He traveled to India, South Africa, Latin America, and within the United States for its market-oriented planning and management educational programs. His clients included [[Dow Chemical Company]], [[Rockwell International]], [[Steelcase]], [[Bemis Manufacturing Company]], [[ALFA (Mexico)|Grupo Industrial Alfa]], Coredemex, [[Lear Siegler]], the Sarns division of [[3M]], and [[United Nations]] businessmen in Costa Rica.<ref name="PII">{{cite web | title= Dr. E. Jerome McCarthy | website=Planned Innovation Institute | url=http://plannedinnovationinstitute.com/pii-mccarthy.html | accessdate=November 4, 2016 }}</ref>
===Membership and awards=== McCarthy was a member of the American Marketing Association and the Economics Society.<ref name=PR /> In 1987, he received the [[American Marketing Association]]'s Trailblazer Award. He was also named one of the "top five" leaders in marketing thought by marketing educators.<ref name="Basic Marketing - Author's notes" />
==Personal life== McCarthy and his wife, Joanne, had eight children. He died December 3, 2015.<ref name=Obituary />
The McCarthys established the Joanne N. and E. Jerome McCarthy Endowment for Arts Education,<ref name=Obituary /> which has supported the [[Wharton Center for Performing Arts]] on the Michigan State University campus.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.whartoncenter.com/support/endowments | title=Endowments | website=Wharton Center for Performing Arts, Michigan State University | location=Lansing| accessdate=November 4, 2016 }}</ref>

'''School leadership''' is the process of enlisting and guiding the talents and energies of [[teacher]]s, [[pupil]]s, and [[parent]]s toward achieving common [[education]]al aims. This term is often used synonymously with '''educational leadership''' in the United States and has supplanted [[educational management]] in the United Kingdom. Several universities in the United States offer graduate degrees in educational leadership.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gradschools.com/search-programs/educational-leadership|title=Educational Leadership Graduate Programs and Graduate Schools|date=16 December 2014|publisher=}}</ref> Certain obstacles of educational leadership can be overcome.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Johnson |first1=Susan Moore |last2=Donaldson |first2=Morgaen L. |title=Educational Leadership |url=http://www.ascd.org/publications/educational-leadership/sept07/vol65/num01/Overcoming-the-Obstacles-to-Leadership.aspx |ref=webpage}}</ref> A self-assessment technique can help examine equity and justice that affects student diversity, especially with selection of candidates.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Karanxha |first1=Zorka |journal=Journal of Research on Leadership Education |title=The Hidden Curriculum: Candidate diversity in Educational Leadership Preparation |volume=9 |number=1 |pages=36–43 |date=August 6, 2013 |doi=10.1177/1942775113498374 |url=http://jrl.sagepub.com/content/9/1/34.full.pdf+html |ref=journal}}</ref>
==History== The term ''school leadership'' came into currency in the late 20th century for several reasons. Demands were made on schools for higher levels of pupil achievement, and schools were expected to improve and reform. These expectations were accompanied by calls for accountability at the school level. Maintenance of the ''status quo'' was no longer considered acceptable. ''Administration'' and ''management'' are terms that connote stability through the exercise of control and supervision. The concept of leadership was favored because it conveys dynamism and pro-activity. The [[Head teacher|principal]] or school head is commonly thought to be the school leader; however, school leadership may include other persons, such as members of a formal leadership team and other persons who contribute toward the aims of the school.
While ''school leadership'' or ''educational leadership'' have become popular as replacements for ''educational administration'' in recent years, ''leadership'' arguably presents only a partial picture of the work of school, division or district, and ministerial or state education agency personnel, not to mention the areas of research explored by [[Faculty (university)|university faculty]] in departments concerned with the operations of schools and educational institutions. For this reason, there may be grounds to question the merits of the term as a catch-all for the field. Rather, the [[etiology]] of its use may be found in more generally and con-temporarily experienced [[neoliberalism|neo-liberal]] social and economic governance models, especially in the United States and the United Kingdom. On this view, the term is understood as having been borrowed from business.
In the United States, the [[Superintendent (education)|superintendency]], or role of the chief school administrator, has undergone many changes since the creation of the position—which is often attributed to the [[Buffalo Common Council]] that approved a superintendent on June 9, 1837. If history serves us correctly, the superintendency is about 170 years old with four major role changes from the early 19th century through the first half of the 20th century and into the early years of the 21st century. Initially, the superintendent's main function was clerical in nature and focused on assisting the board of education with day-to-day details of running the school. At the turn of the 20th century, states began to develop common [[curriculum]] for public schools with superintendents fulfilling the role of teacher-scholar or master educator who had added an emphasis on curricular and instructional matters to school operations. In the early 20th century, the [[Industrial Revolution]] affected the superintendent's role by shifting the emphasis to expert manager with efficiency in handling non-instructional tasks such as budget, facility, and transportation. The release of ''A Nation at Risk ''in 1983 directly impacted public school accountability and, ultimately, the superintendency. The early 1980s initiated the change that has continued through today with the superintendent viewed as chief executive officer, including the roles of professional adviser to the [[Board of education|board]], leader of reforms, manager of resources and communicator to the public.
==Graduate studies== The term "educational leadership" is also used to describe programs beyond schools. Leaders in community colleges, proprietary colleges, community-based programs, and [[University|universities]] are also ''educational leaders''.
Some United States university graduate [[Master's degree|masters]] and [[Doctor of Philosophy|doctoral]] programs are organized with [[higher education]] and [[adult education]] programs as a part of an educational leadership department. In these cases, the entire department is charged with educating ''educational leaders'' with specific specialization areas such as university leadership, [[community college]] leadership, and community-based leadership (as well as school leadership). [[Master's degree|Masters of education]] are offered at a number of universities around the United States in traditional and online formats including the [[University of Texas at El Paso]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://coe.utep.edu/edlf/|title=College of Education|website=coe.utep.edu}}</ref> [[University of Massachusetts]], [[Saint Mary's University of Minnesota]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Online Masters in Educational Leadership|url=http://onlineprograms.smumn.edu/mael/masters-in-educational-leadership|publisher=[[Saint Mary's University of Minnesota]]}}</ref> [[Pepperdine University]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://gsep.pepperdine.edu/masters-educational-leadership-administration/|title=MA in Administrative Services - Master of Arts in Educational Administration Degree Program - Pepperdine University GSEP|website=gsep.pepperdine.edu}}</ref> [[Capella University]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.capella.edu/online-degrees/masters-leadership-educational-administration/|title=Masters in Educational Leadership & Administration Online - Capella University|website=www.capella.edu}}</ref> [[Northcentral University]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ncu.edu/programs-degrees/education/educational-leadership|title=Educational Leadership}} {{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130520032503/https://www.ncu.edu/school-of-education/doctor-of-philosophy-in-education/educational-leadership/|archivedate=2013-05-20|url=https://www.ncu.edu/school-of-education/doctor-of-philosophy-in-education/educational-leadership/|title=Original link}}</ref> and the [[University of Scranton]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Master of Educational Administration|url=http://www.uscranton.com/online-educational-administration/|publisher=[[University of Scranton]]}}</ref> Some United States [[Graduate school|graduate programs]] with a tradition of graduate education in these areas of specialization have separate departments for them. The area of higher education may include areas such as student affairs leadership, academic affairs leadership, community college leadership, community college and university teaching, [[Vocational education|vocational]], adult education and university administration, and educational wings of nongovernmental organizations.
In Europe, similar degrees exist at the [[University of Bath]] and [[Apsley Business School - London]], where the focus is on the management systems of education, especially as British schools move away from state funding to semi-autonomous Free Schools and Academies.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/abs/10.2304/rcie.2011.6.2.170|title=Free Choice, Free Schools and the Academisation of Education in England|first=Paul|last=Miller|date=1 June 2011|publisher=|journal=Research in Comparative and International Education|volume=6|issue=2|pages=170–182|via=SAGE Journals|doi=10.2304/rcie.2011.6.2.170}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://apsley.eu/portfolio-view/mba-in-educational-leadership/|title=MBA in Educational Leadership|website=apsley.eu}}</ref> In fact in these schools, the focus is on traditional MBA disciplines, such as HR, Change Management and Finance. The so-called "Academisation" of British education is highly contentious and political issue <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/education/2013/feb/11/academies-schools-education-policy|title=The headteachers who fought off the academy brokers|first=Rhonda|last=Evans|date=11 February 2013|publisher=|via=The Guardian}}</ref> with many headteachers resisting moves to what they see as forced privatization.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://schoolsweek.co.uk/schools-requiring-improvement-face-academisation/|title=Schools ‘requiring improvement’ face academisation - Schools Week|date=2 February 2015|publisher=}}</ref> In mainland Europe, Educational Leadership is not taught formally, with senior educationalists having come through academic pathways, not administration <ref>{{cite journal|url=http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/abs/10.3102/0013189X021004004|title=Educational Leadership and the Crisis of Democratic Government|first=Henry A.|last=Giroux|date=1 May 1992|publisher=|journal=Educational Researcher|volume=21|issue=4|pages=4–11|via=SAGE Journals|doi=10.3102/0013189X021004004}}</ref>
==Literature, research and policy== {{unreferenced section|date=September 2015}} Educational leadership draws upon interdisciplinary literature, generally, but ideally distinguishes itself through its focus on [[pedagogy]], [[epistemology]] and [[Developmental psychology|human development]]. In contemporary practice it borrows from [[political science]] and business. Debate within the field relates to this tension. Numerous educational leadership theories and perspectives have been presented and explored, such as: (a) [[instructional leadership]]; (b) [[Distributed Leadership|distributed leadership]]; (c) transformational leadership; (d) [[social justice educational leadership|social justice leadership]]; and (e) [[Teacher leadership]]. Researchers have explored how different practices and actions impact student achievement, teacher job satisfaction, or other elements related to school improvement. Moreover, researchers continue to investigate the methodology and quality of principal preparation programs.
A number of publications and foundations are devoted to studying the particular requirements of leadership in these settings, and educational leadership is taught as an academic discipline at a number of universities.
Several countries now have explicit policies on school leadership, including policies and budgets for the training and development of school leaders.
In the USA, formal "curriculum audits" are becoming common, in which educational leaders and trained auditors evaluate school leadership and the alignment of curriculum with goals and objectives. Curriculum audits and [[curriculum mapping]] were developed by [[Fenwick W. English]] in the late 1970s. The educational leaders and auditors who conduct the audits are certified by [[Phi Delta Kappa]]. Research shows how educational leadership influences student learning.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Leithwood|first1=Kenneth|title=educational leadership|journal=educational leadership influences student learning|pages=3–36|url=http://www.wallacefoundation.org/knowledge-center/school-leadership/key-research/documents/how-leadership-influences-student-learning.pdf|ref=article}}</ref>

'''FitzPatrick 1932''' is an early paper in the field of [[bankruptcy prediction]]. In a series of three articles in the monthly ''The Certified Public Accountant'' in 1932, Paul J. FitzPatrick presented data for 20 matched pairs of firms and discussed accounting ratios as indicators of bankruptcy. It is historically significant as an early attempt in this field, and it is notable also for its publishing a data set, now in the public domain. Beaver (1968), an important paper in accounting research which employs statistical analysis to a similar matched sample, cites the paper.
The dataset includes 13 accounting ratios calculated for 40 firms for each of three years. However some fields are missing for some firm-year observations.
