Goodling]] |successor3 = [[Howard McKeon]] |office4 = [[Republican Conference Chairman of the United States House of Representatives|Chair of the House Republican Conference]] |leader4 = [[Newt Gingrich]] |term_start4 = January 3, 1995 |term_end4 = January 3, 1999 |predecessor4 = [[Dick Armey]] |successor4 = [[J. C. Watts]] |state5 = [[Ohio]] |district5 = {{ushr|OH|8|8th}} |term_start5 = January 3, 1991 |term_end5 = October 31, 2015 |predecessor5 = [[Buz Lukens]] |successor5 = [[Warren Davidson]] |state_house6 = Ohio |district6 = 57th |term_start6 = January 3, 1985 |term_end6 = December 31, 1990 |predecessor6 = [[Bill Donham]] |successor6 = [[Scott Nein]] |birth_name = John Andrew Boehner |birth_date = {{nowrap|{{birth date and age|1949|11|17}}}} |birth_place = [[Reading, Ohio]], U.S. |death_date = |death_place = |party = [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] |spouse = {{marriage|Deborah Gunlack|1973}} |children = 2 |education = [[Xavier University]] ([[Bachelor of Arts|BA]]) |signature = John Boehner Signature.svg |allegiance = {{flag|United States}} |branch = {{flag|United States Navy}} |serviceyears = 1968 (8 weeks) }} '''John Andrew Boehner''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|b|eɪ|n|ər}} {{respell|BAY|nər}}; born {{nowrap|November 17}}, 1949) is an American politician who served as the [[List of Speakers of the United States House of Representatives|53rd]] [[Speaker of the United States House of Representatives]] from 2011 to 2015.{{cite news| url=http://www.cnn.com/2011/POLITICS/01/05/pelosi.boehner/index.html | work=CNN | title=Boehner takes charge as new Congress convenes | date=January 5, 2011}} A member of the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]], he was the [[United States House of Representatives|U.S. Representative]] for {{ushr|OH|8}} from 1991 to 2015. The district included several rural and suburban areas near [[Cincinnati]] and [[Dayton, Ohio|Dayton]]. Boehner previously served as the [[Minority Leader of the United States House of Representatives|House Minority Leader]] from 2007 until 2011, and [[Majority Leader of the United States House of Representatives|House Majority Leader]] from 2006 until 2007. Boehner's almost nine years as the Republican Leader in the House (four years as Minority Leader and nearly five years as Speaker) was the longest consecutive tenure for a Republican Leader in the House since [[Robert H. Michel|Bob Michel]] of Illinois served 14 years as House Minority Leader between 1981 and 1995. Boehner resigned from the House of Representatives in October 2015 due to opposition from within the Republican caucus. In September 2016, [[Squire Patton Boggs]], the third largest lobbying firm in the U.S., announced that Boehner would join their firm. It was also announced that Boehner would become a board member of [[Reynolds American]], the second biggest tobacco firm in the U.S., for an estimated annual salary of $400,000.{{cite web|url=http://fortune.com/2016/09/20/john-boehner-squire-patton-boggs/ |title=John Boehner Joins Squire Patton Boggs, Law Firm Known for Lobbying |publisher=Fortune.com |date= |accessdate=2017-03-01}} == Early life, education, and career == Boehner was born in [[Reading, Ohio]], the son of Mary Anne (née Hall; 1926–1998) and Earl Henry Boehner (1925–1990), the second of twelve children. His father was of [[German American|German]] descent and his mother had German and [[Irish American|Irish]] ancestry.{{refn|{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/northamerica/usa/8009943/John-Boehner-the-second-of-12-kids-from-Ohio-who-is-Barack-Obamas-elitist-target.html |title=John Boehner: the second of twelve kids |work=The Daily Telegraph |accessdate=September 14, 2010 | location=London | first=Toby | last=Harnden}}{{cite web |url=https://www.facebook.com/photo.php?fbid=175380149169318&set=a.175380095835990.35084.175082565865743 |title=Office of Speaker Boehner's Photos – January 2011 |publisher=Facebook}}{{cite web|url=http://johnboehner.house.gov/Biography |title=John Boehner – 8th District of Ohio |publisher=U.S. House of Representatives |accessdate=July 13, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090513191556/http://johnboehner.house.gov/Biography/ |archivedate=May 13, 2009 }}{{cite book|last=Thompson |first=Clifford |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4yZnDW7PT4QC&q=%22Earl+Henry+Boehner%22+HALL |title=Current Biography Yearbook 2006 |year=2006 |publisher=H.W. Wilson Company |page=58 |isbn=978-0-8242-1074-8}}{{cite web|url=http://freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~battle/reps/boehner.htm |title=boehner |publisher=Freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.ancestry.com |date= |accessdate=October 28, 2013}}}} He grew up in modest circumstances, having shared one bathroom with his eleven siblings in a two-bedroom house in Cincinnati.{{cite news |url=http://abcnews.go.com/WN/american-dream-john-boehner-set-house-helm/story?id=12048868&page=1 |title='American Dream': John Boehner Set to Take House Helm |work=ABC News |date=November 3, 2010 |first=Susie |last=Banikarim |first2=Enjoli |last2=Francis }} He started working at his family's bar at age 8, a business founded by their grandfather Andy Boehner in 1938. He has lived in Southwest Ohio his entire life.{{cite news| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/northamerica/usa/8009943/John-Boehner-the-second-of-12-kids-from-Ohio-who-is-Barack-Obamas-elitist-target.html | location=London | work=The Daily Telegraph | first=Toby | last=Harnden | title=John Boehner: the second of 12 kids from Ohio who is Barack Obama's elitist target | date=September 17, 2010}}{{cite news|last=Grunwald |first=Michael |first2=Jay |last2=Newton-Small |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,2029476-2,00.html |title=Tanned, Tested, Ready: John Boehner |publisher=Time |date=November 5, 2010 |accessdate=October 28, 2013}} Boehner attended Cincinnati's [[Moeller High School]] and was a [[linebacker]] on the school's football team, where he was coached by future [[Notre Dame Fighting Irish football|Notre Dame]] coach [[Gerry Faust]].{{refn|{{cite video|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/21134540/vp/40955940|title=Boehner talks about tearfulness: 'It's who I am'|people=[[Brian Williams]] (interviewer) and John Boehner (interviewee)|work=[[NBC Nightly News]]|date=January 6, 2011|time=3:03}}{{cite news|url=http://www.newyorker.com/reporting/2010/12/13/101213fa_fact_boyer?currentPage=all|title=House Rule|work=The New Yorker|date=December 13, 2010|author=Peter J. Boyer}}{{cite news|url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/onpolitics/post/2010/12/john-boehner-speaker-new-yorker-/1|title=Boehner: Tea Party rally showed him need for strong GOP|work=USA Today|date=December 6, 2010|author=Catalina Camia}}{{cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2010/10/21/politics/main6979283.shtml|title=John Boehner: Speaker-in-Waiting?|publisher=[[CBS News]]|date=October 21, 2010}}{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/15/us/politics/15boehner.html|title=Boehner's Path to Power Began in Southern Ohio|work=The New York Times|author=Jennifer Steinhauer and Carl Hulse|date=October 14, 2010}}{{cite news|url=http://news.cincinnati.com/article/20101004/NEWS0108/110040002/John-Boehner-rose-from-humble-roots|title=John Boehner rose from humble roots|work=[[Cincinnati Enquirer]]|date=October 4, 2010|author=Eric Bradley}}{{cite news|url=http://articles.cnn.com/2010-08-31/politics/boehner.profile_1_boehner-john-boehner-house-gop|archive-url=https://archive.is/20120707172334/http://articles.cnn.com/2010-08-31/politics/boehner.profile_1_boehner-john-boehner-house-gop|dead-url=yes|archive-date=July 7, 2012|title=President's critic powerful insider, little-known outside the Beltway|publisher=CNN|date=August 31, 2010|author=Deirdre Walsh}}}} Graduating from Moeller in 1968, when United States involvement in the [[Vietnam War]] was at its peak, Boehner enlisted in the [[United States Navy]] but was [[honorable discharge|honorably discharged]] after eight weeks because of a bad back.[http://www.enquirer.com/editions/2002/09/23/loc_military_service.html Weiser, Carl. "Military service rare on delegation," ''Cincinnati Enquirer'', 23 September 2002], accessed October 12, 2013. He earned his [[Bachelor of Arts|B.A.]] in [[business administration]] from [[Xavier University (Cincinnati)|Xavier University]] in 1977, becoming the first person in his family to attend college, taking seven years as he held several jobs to pay for his education. Shortly after his graduation in 1977, Boehner accepted a position with Nucite Sales, a small sales business in the packaging and [[plastics industry]]. He was steadily promoted and eventually became president of the firm, resigning in 1990 when he was elected to Congress. == Early political career == From 1981 to 1984, Boehner served on the board of trustees of [[Union Township, Butler County, Ohio]]. He then served as an [[Ohio House of Representatives|Ohio state representative]] from 1985 to 1990.[http://history.house.gov/People/Detail/9538 Boehner, John Andrew]. US House of Representatives: History, Art & Archives. Retrieved March 16, 2015. == U.S. House of Representatives == [[File:Representative John Boehner in 1993 (cropped).jpg|thumb|Boehner in 1993]] In 1990, Boehner ran against incumbent Congressman [[Buz Lukens]], who was under fire for having a sexual relationship with a minor. In a three-way Republican primary that included Boehner, Lukens, and former Congressman [[Tom Kindness]], Boehner won with 49 percent of the vote.{{cite news|last1=Alberta|first1=Tim|title=John Boehner Unchained|url=https://www.politico.com/magazine/story/2017/10/29/john-boehner-trump-house-republican-party-retirement-profile-feature-215741|accessdate=30 October 2017|publisher=Politio|date=1 November 2017}} He then handily beat his Democratic opponent, [[Greg Jolivette]], in the [[United States House of Representatives elections, 1990|November election]]. He was subsequently re-elected to Congress 12 times, each by a substantial margin. === Gang of Seven and ''Contract with America'' === During his freshman year, Boehner was a member of the [[Gang of Seven]] which was involved in bringing media attention to the [[House banking scandal]].[https://www.nytimes.com/2009/07/05/us/politics/05boehner.html A Rabble-Rouser, Then and Now], New York Times, Carl Hulse, July 4, 2009 The group also [[Congressional Post Office scandal|investigated]] the Congressional Post Office, leading to the indictment of Congressman [[Dan Rostenkowski]]. Later, he, along with [[Newt Gingrich]] and several other Republican lawmakers, was one of the engineers of the ''[[Contract with America]]'' in 1994 that politically helped Republicans during the [[United States elections, 1994|1994 congressional elections]] during which they won the majority in Congress for the first time in four decades. === Republican leadership === From 1995 to 1999, Boehner served as [[Republican Conference Chairman of the United States House of Representatives|House Republican Conference Chairman]], making him fourth-ranking House Republican behind Gingrich, [[House Majority Leader|Majority Leader]] [[Dick Armey]] and [[House Majority Whip|Majority Whip]] [[Tom DeLay]]. During his time as Conference Chairman, Boehner championed the [[Federal Agriculture Improvement and Reform Act of 1996|Freedom to Farm Act]] that, among other provisions, revised and simplified direct payment programs for crops and eliminated milk price supports through direct government purchases. In the summer of 1997 several House Republicans, who saw [[Speaker of the United States House of Representatives|Speaker]] [[Newt Gingrich]]'s public image as a liability, attempted to replace him as Speaker. The attempted "coup" began July 9 with a meeting between Republican conference chairman Boehner and Republican leadership chairman [[Bill Paxon]] of New York. According to their plan, [[Party leaders of the United States House of Representatives|House Majority Leader]] [[Dick Armey]], [[Party whips of the United States House of Representatives|House Majority Whip]] [[Tom DeLay]], Boehner and Paxon were to present Gingrich with an ultimatum: resign, or be voted out. However, Armey balked at the proposal to make Paxon the new Speaker, and told his chief of staff to warn Gingrich about the coup.{{Cite news| url=http://www.cnn.com/ALLPOLITICS/1997/07/21/time/gingrich.html |publisher=CNN|title=Attempted Republican Coup: Ready, Aim, Misfire|accessdate=May 20, 2010}} On July 11, Gingrich met with senior Republican leadership to assess the situation. He explained that under no circumstance would he step down. If he was voted out, there would be a new election for Speaker, which would allow for the possibility that Democrats—along with dissenting Republicans—would vote in [[Dick Gephardt]] as Speaker. On July 16, Paxon offered to resign his post, feeling that he had not handled the situation correctly. Paxon was the only unelected member of the leadership group, having been appointed to his position by Gingrich.{{cite book |title=Lessons Learned the Hard Way |last=Gingrich |first=Newt |year=1998 |publisher=HarperCollins Publishers |isbn=978-0-06-019106-1 |pages=159–160}} After Republicans lost seats in the [[United States elections, 1998|1998 elections]], the House Republican leadership underwent a reorganization. Armey and DeLay kept their positions, but Gingrich was replaced by [[Dennis Hastert]], and Boehner lost his position as conference chairman to [[J.C. Watts]]. === Chairman of Committee on Education and Labor === [[File:Boehnerandstivers.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Boehner, as House Minority Leader, campaigns for fellow Ohio Congressman [[Steve Stivers]] (left) during the [[United States House of Representatives elections in Ohio, 2010|2010 midterm elections]]|alt=]] Following the election of President [[George W. Bush]], Boehner was elected as chairman of the [[U.S. House Committee on Education and the Workforce|House Education and the Workforce Committee]], serving from 2001 until 2006. There he authored several reforms including the [[Pension Protection Act of 2006|Pension Protection Act]] and a successful school choice voucher program for low-income children in Washington, DC.{{cite news |author=George F. Will |url=http://pittsburghlive.com/x/pittsburghtrib/opinion/columnists/will/s_154631.html |title=Today's principle civil rights fight |newspaper=Pittsburgh Tribune-Review |date=September 14, 2003 |accessdate=August 23, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120720204738/http://pittsburghlive.com/x/pittsburghtrib/opinion/columnists/will/s_154631.html |archivedate=July 20, 2012 |df=mdy-all }} Boehner and Senator [[Ted Kennedy]] authored the passage of the [[No Child Left Behind Act of 2001]], which was signed by President George W. Bush in 2002.{{cite news|last=Rotherham |first=Andrew J. |url=http://www.time.com/time/nation/article/0,8599,2029309,00.html |title=Will John Boehner Be Good for Education? |publisher=Time |date=November 4, 2010 |accessdate=October 28, 2013}} Boehner said that it was his "proudest achievement" in two decades of public service.{{cite conference|first=Andrew |last=Rudalevige|title=Accountability and Avoidance in the Bush Education Plan: The 'No Child Left Behind Act of 2001.'|booktitle="Taking Account of Accountability" Conference, Program on Education Policy and Governance|date=June 10, 2002|location=Kennedy School of Government, Harvard University|url=http://users.dickinson.edu/~rudaleva/ed_final.pdf}} Boehner was friends with Kennedy, also a Roman Catholic, and every year they chaired fundraisers for cash-strapped Catholic schools.{{cite news|last=Grunwald |first=Michael |first2=Jay |last2=Newton-Small |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,2029476,00.html |title=Tanned, Tested, Ready: John Boehner |publisher=Time |date=November 5, 2010 |accessdate=October 28, 2013}} === House Republican Leader === [[File:John Boehner portrait.jpg|thumb|right|upright|2006 portrait of Boehner]] Delay resigned as Majority Leader in 2005 after being indicted, and Boehner, House Majority Whip [[Roy Blunt]] of [[Missouri]], and Representative [[John Shadegg]] of [[Arizona]], all sought to succeed Delay. Boehner campaigned as a reform candidate who wanted to reform the so-called "[[Earmark (politics)|earmark]]" process and rein in government spending. In the second round of voting by the House Republican Conference, Boehner defeated Blunt with 122 to 109 votes. Blunt kept his previous position as Majority Whip, the No. 3 leadership position in the House. (There was some confusion on the first ballot for Majority Leader as the first count showed one more vote cast than Republicans present,{{cite web|url=http://rollcall.com/issues/1_1/breakingnews/12015-1.html |title=Roll Call |accessdate=2006-02-04 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060204102043/http://rollcall.com/issues/1_1/breakingnews/12015-1.html |archivedate=February 4, 2006 |df=mdy }} due to a misunderstanding as to whether the rules allowed Resident Commissioner [[Luis Fortuño]] of Puerto Rico to vote).{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/0602/02/lol.01.html |title=CNN |publisher=CNN |date=February 2, 2006 |accessdate=June 14, 2010}} After the Republicans lost control of the House in the 2006 elections, the House Republican Conference chose Boehner as Minority Leader. While as Majority Leader he was second-in-command behind Speaker Dennis Hastert, as Minority Leader he was the leader of the House Republicans. As such, he was the Republican nominee for Speaker in 2006 and 2008, losing both times to Pelosi. According to the 2008 Congress.org Power Ranking, Boehner was the 6th most powerful congressman (preceded by Speaker Pelosi, Majority Leader Hoyer, Ways and Means Committee Chairman [[Sander M. Levin]], Dean of the House [[John Dingell]], and Appropriations Committee Chairman [[Dave Obey]], all Democrats) and the most powerful Republican.{{cite web|url=http://www.congress.org/congressorg/power_rankings/overall.tt |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-04-25 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080918155340/http://www.congress.org/congressorg/power_rankings/overall.tt |archivedate=September 18, 2008 |df=mdy }} As Minority Leader, Boehner served as an ''ex officio'' member of the [[United States House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence|Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence]]. == Speaker of the House == [[File:Obama Boehner State of the Union 2011.jpg|thumb|Speaker Boehner greets U.S. President [[Barack Obama]] before the [[2011 State of the Union Address]]]] The Republicans won a majority in the House of Representatives during the 2010 midterm elections, with a net gain of 63 seats. During his solemn victory speech, Boehner broke into tears when talking about "economic freedom, individual liberty and personal responsibility...I hold these values dear because I've lived them...I've spent my whole life chasing the American Dream". On November 17, 2010, Boehner was unanimously chosen by the House Republicans as their nominee for Speaker,{{cite web|url=http://gopleader.gov/News/DocumentSingle.aspx?DocumentID=215305 |title=Boehner: New Leadership "Reflects a New Majority Ready to Listen and Go to Work |publisher=Office of the House Republican Leader |date=November 17, 2010 |accessdate=November 19, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101122033220/http://gopleader.gov/News/DocumentSingle.aspx?DocumentID=215305 |archivedate=November 22, 2010 }}{{cite web|url=http://thehill.com/homenews/house/129727-boehner-elected-61st-speaker-of-the-house-on-his-61st-birthday|title=Boehner favored as 61st House Speaker on his 61st birthday |publisher=TheHill.com |date=November 17, 2010 |accessdate=November 17, 2010}} all but assuring his formal election to the post when the new Congress convened with a Republican majority in January 2011. He received the gavel from outgoing Speaker Pelosi on Wednesday, January 5, 2011.{{cite news|last=Sanburn |first=Josh |url=http://www.time.com/time/politics/article/0,8599,2041119,00.html |title=Boehner's Large Gavel: Why Is New Speaker's Gavel So Big? |publisher=Time |date=January 6, 2011 |accessdate=October 28, 2013}} He was the first Speaker from Ohio since fellow Republicans [[Nicholas Longworth]] (1925 to 1931) and [[J. Warren Keifer]] (1881 to 1883). He was also the first Speaker who has served both as majority and minority floor leader for his party since Texas Democrat [[Sam Rayburn]].{{citation needed|date=January 2013}} [[File:Pope Francis and Speaker Boehner.jpg|thumb|left|Speaker Boehner meets with [[Pope Francis]] during [[Pope Francis' visit to the United States|his visit]] to the United States Congress]] As Speaker, he was still the leader of the House Republicans. However, by tradition, he normally did not take part in debate, although he had the right to do so, and almost never voted from the floor.{{cite web |url=http://votesmart.org/candidate/key-votes/27015/john-boehner |title=Representative John Boehner's Voting Records |publisher=[[Project Vote Smart]] |accessdate=October 11, 2013}} He was not a member of any House committees during his Speakership. Boehner was narrowly re-elected as Speaker of the House on January 3, 2013 at the beginning of the [[113th United States Congress]].{{cite news|url=http://fivethirtyeight.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/01/04/were-the-g-o-p-votes-against-boehner-a-historic-rejection/|title=Were the G.O.P. Votes Against Boehner a Historic Rejection?|last=Silver|first=Nate|date=January 4, 2013|work=The New York Times|accessdate=January 8, 2013}} He received 220 votes, needing 214 to win.{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/boehner-reelected-as-house-speaker/2013/01/03/c60b0970-55cb-11e2-8b9e-dd8773594efc_story.html|title=John Boehner reelected as House speaker|last=Kane|first=Paul|date=January 3, 2013|work=The Washington Post|accessdate=January 4, 2013}} Boehner appeared on ''[[The Tonight Show with Jay Leno]]'' on January 23, 2014. When asked by [[Jay Leno|Leno]] if he would ever run for president, the Speaker said no, adding, "I like to play golf. I like to cut my own grass. I do drink red wine, I smoke cigarettes. And I'm not giving that up to be President of the United States."{{cite web|last=Richter|first=Greg|title=Boehner Tells Leno He Won't Give Up Wine, Golf to Be President|url=http://www.newsmax.com/Newsfront/boehner-leno-gop-washington/2014/01/23/id/548769|publisher=Newsmax|accessdate=January 25, 2014}} In July 2014, Boehner moved forward on a [[United States House of Representatives v. Obama|lawsuit]] to force the President to impose penalties on companies who failed to provide health care coverage for their employees.{{cite news |url=http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/wireStory/boehner-disagrees-call-obama-impeachment-24505648 |title=House GOP Moves Ahead on Suing Obama |last1=CASSATA |first1=DONNA |date=July 10, 2014 |website=abcnews.go.com |agency=Associated Press |accessdate=July 10, 2014}} Boehner had pressed for legislation to delay this mandate the previous year.{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2014/07/11/politics/republicans-obamacare-white-house-sue/ |title=White House: GOP voted to delay Obamacare mandate |last1=Acosta |first1=Jim |date=July 11, 2014 |website=www.cnn.com |publisher=CNN |accessdate=July 11, 2014}} The third law firm selected finally filed the suit in November 2014, after Boehner criticized Obama's unilateral moves on immigration policy.{{cite news |url=http://www.stripes.com/house-republicans-sue-obama-over-affordable-care-act-enactment-1.315574 |title=House Republicans sue Obama over Affordable Care Act enactment |last1=Levey |first1=Noam N. |date=November 22, 2014 |website=www.stripes.com |publisher=Tribune Washington Bureau |accessdate=November 22, 2014}} === Resignation === {{See also|Speaker of the United States House of Representatives election, October 2015}} [[File:Speaker's Farewell.tif|thumb|300px|Speaker Boehner looks at the National Mall from the Speaker's balcony at the U.S. Capitol for one of the final times before leaving office]] On September 25, 2015, Boehner announced that he would step down as Speaker and resign from Congress at the end of October 2015. Boehner's resignation took place after [[Pope Francis]]' [[Pope Francis' visit to the United States|address to Congress the day before]], an event considered by Boehner personally as the highest point in his legislative career. Sources in his office indicated he was stepping aside in the face of increasing discord while trying to manage passage of a continuing resolution to fund the government. Conservative opposition to funding [[Planned Parenthood]] as part of the resolution, and stronger threats to Boehner's leadership on account of the controversy, prompted the abrupt announcement.{{cite news|title=John Boehner Will Resign From Congress|first=Jennifer |last=Steinhauer |work=[[The New York Times]]|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/26/us/boehner-will-resign-from-congress.html|date=September 25, 2015|accessdate=October 8, 2015}} Originally, House Majority Leader [[Kevin McCarthy (California politician)|Kevin McCarthy]] of California had announced he would run for Speaker and was seen as the prohibitive favorite. On October 8, 2015, McCarthy abruptly announced he would not run for Speaker, citing that he felt he could not effectively lead a fractured Republican Caucus. After McCarthy's announcement, Boehner announced that he would stay on as Speaker until a successor was chosen.{{cite web |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/powerpost/wp/2015/10/08/house-majority-leader-kevin-mccarthy-drops-out-of-race-for-house-speaker/ |title=House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy drops out of race for House speaker |work=Washington Post |authors=Mike DeBonis, Robert Costa and Rosalind S. Helderman |date=October 8, 2015 |accessdate=October 31, 2015}} After initially turning down requests from Republican leaders, [[United States House Committee on Ways and Means|House Ways and Means Committee Chairman]] and [[Vice presidential candidacy of Paul Ryan|2012 Republican Vice Presidential nominee]] [[Paul Ryan]] of Wisconsin announced he would run for Speaker and had received Boehner's blessing.{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/10/21/politics/paul-ryan-house-speaker-freedom-caucus/ |title=After caucus vote, Paul Ryan is pushing ahead with speaker bid |work=CNN.com |authors=Manu Raju, Deirdre Walsh, Tal Kopan and Dana Bash, |date=October 21, 2015 |accessdate=October 31, 2015}} In his final act as Speaker, Boehner presided over the election to succeed him. After announcing that Ryan had garnered a majority of votes on the House floor, Boehner officially passed off the Speaker's gavel to Ryan on October 29, 2015.{{cite web |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/powerpost/wp/2015/10/29/paul-ryan-set-to-be-elected-62nd-house-speaker/ |title=Paul Ryan elected House speaker |work=Washington Post |author=Mike DeBonis |date=October 29, 2015 |accessdate=October 31, 2015}} Boehner's resignation from Congress became official October 31, 2015, at 11:59 p.m.{{cite web |url=http://www.cleveland.com/open/index.ssf/2015/10/john_boehner_exits_john_kasich.html |title=John Boehner exits, John Kasich books Stephen Colbert: Ohio Politics Roundup |work=Cleveland.com |author=Henry J. Gomez |date=October 30, 2015 |accessdate=October 31, 2015}} == Controversies == {{criticism section|date=June 2015}} === Connections to lobbyists === In June 1995, Boehner distributed campaign contributions from [[tobacco industry]] [[lobbyist]]s on the House floor as House members were weighing how to vote on tobacco subsidies.{{cite news|author=Dana Milbank |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/02/02/AR2006020202571_pf.html |title=Boehner Makes His Political Comeback |work=Washington Post |date=February 3, 2006 |accessdate=November 22, 2010}} In a 1996 documentary by [[PBS]] called ''The People and the Power Game'', Boehner said "They asked me to give out a half dozen checks quickly before we got to the end of the month and I complied. And I did it on the House floor, which I regret. I should not have done. It's not a violation of the House rules, but it's a practice that's gone on here for a long time that we're trying to stop and I know I'll never do it again."{{Citation |title='The Rachel Maddow Show' (transcript) |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/39459613 |date=September 30, 2010 }} Boehner eventually led the effort to change House rules and prohibit campaign contributions from being distributed on the House floor.See [http://www.rules.house.gov/ruleprec/109th.pdf House Rule IV 7] at rules.house.gov. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060829022048/http://www.rules.house.gov/ruleprec/109th.pdf |date=August 29, 2006 }} A September 2010 ''[[New York Times]]'' story said Boehner was "Tightly Bound to Lobbyists" and "He maintains especially tight ties with a circle of lobbyists and former aides representing some of the nation's biggest businesses, including Goldman Sachs, Google, Citigroup, R.J. Reynolds, MillerCoors and UPS.".{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/09/12/us/politics/12boehner.html |title=A G.O.P. Leader Tightly Bound to Lobbyists |newspaper=New York Times |date=September 11, 2010 |first=Eric |last=Lipton }} === Smithsonian === In November 2010, Boehner, along with Minority Whip Eric Cantor, called for the cancellation of an exhibit in the [[Smithsonian]]'s [[National Portrait Gallery (United States)|National Portrait Gallery]] after he learned that it featured a video by [[David Wojnarowicz]], ''A Fire in My Belly'', that contained an image of a [[crucifix]] with ants crawling on it. Boehner spokesman Kevin Smith said, "Smithsonian officials should either acknowledge the mistake and correct it, or be prepared to face tough scrutiny beginning in January when the new majority in the House moves [in]."{{cite news| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/11/30/AR2010113006801.html | work=The Washington Post | first=Jacqueline | last=Trescott | title=Portrait Gallery removes crucifix video from exhibit after complaints | date=December 1, 2010}} === Hurricane Sandy relief bill === On January 1, 2013, after passing the [[fiscal cliff]] [[American Taxpayer Relief Act of 2012|deal]], Boehner adjourned the House without passing the $60 million [[Hurricane Sandy relief bill]]. Some Representatives, especially from the Northeast and including Republicans as well as Democrats, and [[New Jersey]] Governor [[Chris Christie]] harshly criticized Boehner.{{cite news|url=http://abcnews.go.com/GMA/video/chris-christie-slams-john-boehner-hurricane-sandy-presser-18120271|title=Gov. Chris Christie Slams GOP Leader Boehner|publisher=ABC news|date= January 2013|accessdate =June 16, 2013}} Boehner later promised to pass the bill.{{cite news|url=http://thehill.com/blogs/on-the-money/budget/275141-boehner-committed-to-passing-sandy-aid-in-jan|title=Boehner committed to move Hurricane Sandy relief bill in January |publisher=The Hill|date= January 2013|accessdate =June 16, 2013}} However, some commentators praised Boehner for not passing a bill they saw as full of [[pork barrel]].{{cite news|url=http://www.redstate.com/2013/01/07/what-did-congress-do-about-hurricane-sandy-rape-it-for-what-its-worth/|title=What Did Congress Do About Hurricane Sandy? Rape it for What It's Worth!|publisher=RedState|date= January 2013|accessdate =June 16, 2013}} === Cromnibus and 2015 House Chair election === Many [[Republican Party (United States)|Republicans]] were ready for a new [[United States House of Representatives|House of Representatives]] Chairman following the 2014 mid-term elections. ''EMC Research'' reported 60% of participants in their telephone survey wanted a new chairman.{{cite news|url=https://www.scribd.com/doc/251502982/National-Telephone-Survey-of-Republican-Voters|title=National Telephone Survey of Republican Voters|publisher=EMC Research|date= January 2014|accessdate =January 5, 2014}} In the end there were a total of 25 votes against Boehner, 29 were needed in order to choose a new speaker. Boehner responded by removing those who opposed him from influential committees.{{cite news|url=http://www.politico.com/story/2015/01/boehner-allies-out-for-revenge-114007.html|title=Boehner takes revenge|publisher=[[Politico]]|date=January 6, 2014|accessdate=January 6, 2014}} == Political positions == [[File:JBoehnerandbush.JPG|thumb|Boehner introducing then-president [[George W. Bush]] in [[Troy, Ohio]] in 2003]] [[File:CPAC 2009 IMG 9962 (3314407560).jpg|thumb|Boehner speaking at the 2009 [[Conservative Political Action Conference]]]] A profile in the ''[[Pittsburgh Tribune-Review]]'' said, "On both sides of the aisle, Boehner earns praise for candor and an ability to listen."{{cite news|url=http://www.pittsburghlive.com/x/pittsburghtrib/news/pittsburgh/s_624471.html|title=Boehner's job: Recapture 'squandered' GOP brand|author=Salena Zito|work=Pittsburgh Tribune-Review|date=May 10, 2009|accessdate=June 3, 2009}}{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ''[[The Plain Dealer]]'' says Boehner "has perfected the art of disagreeing without being disagreeable."{{cite news|url=http://blog.cleveland.com/metro/2009/03/waiting_for_the_banana_peel_ho.html|title=House Republican leader John Boehner of Ohio helps unite GOP|work=The Plain Dealer|author=Sabrina Eaton|date=March 8, 2009|accessdate=June 3, 2009}} Boehner has been classified as a "hard-core conservative" by [[OnTheIssues]].{{cite web|url=http://www.issues2000.org/OH/John_Boehner.htm |title=John Boehner on the Issues |publisher=Issues2000.org |accessdate=June 14, 2010}} Although Boehner has a conservative voting record, when he was running for House leadership, religious conservatives in the GOP expressed that they were not satisfied with his positions. According to the ''[[Washington Post]]'': "From [[illegal immigration]] to sanctions on China to an overhaul of the pension system, Boehner, as chairman of the House Committee on Education and the Workforce, took ardently pro-business positions that were contrary to those of many in his party. Religious conservatives – examining his voting record – see him as a policymaker driven by small-government economic concerns, not theirs."{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/02/11/AR2006021100842.html |title=Washington Post |work=Washington Post |date= February 12, 2006|accessdate=June 14, 2010 | first=Jonathan | last=Weisman}} Boehner opposes [[same-sex marriage in the United States|same-sex marriage]], as evidenced by his vote for the [[Federal Marriage Amendment]] in both 2004 and 2006. In a letter to the [[Human Rights Campaign]], Boehner stated, "I oppose any legislation that would provide special [[LGBT rights by country or territory|rights for homosexuals]]... Please be assured that I will continue to work to protect the idea of [[Traditional family|the traditional family]] as one of the fundamental tenets of [[Western culture|western civilization]]."Equality magazine. Winter 2011 issue. "Vigilance!", page 5.{{cite web|url=http://www.ontheissues.org/OH/John_Boehner_Civil_Rights.htm |title=John Boehner on Civil Rights |publisher=On the Issues |accessdate=October 28, 2013}} On May 25, 2006, Boehner issued a statement defending his agenda and attacking his "[[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]] friends" such as Minority Leader [[Nancy Pelosi]]. Boehner said regarding national security that voters "have a choice between a Republican Party that understands the stakes and is dedicated to victory, and a Democrat Party with a non-existent national security policy that sheepishly dismisses the challenges of a post-[[9/11]] world and is all too willing to concede defeat on the battlefield in [[Iraq]]." Boehner is a signer of [[Taxpayer Protection Pledge|Americans for Tax Reform]]'s [[Taxpayer Protection Pledge]].{{cite web|title=The Taxpayer Protection Pledge Signers 112th Congressional List|url=http://s3.amazonaws.com/atrfiles/files/files/091411-federalpledgesigners.pdf|publisher=Americans for Tax Reform|accessdate=November 30, 2011}} In June 2013, Boehner labeled former NSA contractor [[Edward Snowden]] a traitor after his [[Global surveillance disclosures (2013–present)|leaks]] went public.{{cite news |title=John Boehner: Edward Snowden Is A 'Traitor' |work=[[San Francisco Chronicle]] |date=June 11, 2013 |last= LoGiurato |first= Brett |url= http://www.sfgate.com/technology/businessinsider/article/JOHN-BOEHNER-Edward-Snowden-Is-A-Traitor-4593261.php }} "I'm not qualified to debate the science over [[climate change]]," Boehner said at a press conference on May 29, 2014 at which he criticized proposed federal regulations on [[Fossil-fuel power station|coal-fired power plants]].{{cite news |title=Boehner 'not qualified' to debate climate change |first=Russell |last=Berman |url=http://thehill.com/policy/energy-environment/207580-boehner-not-qualified-to-debate-climate-change |publisher=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]] |date=May 29, 2014 |accessdate=March 20, 2015}}{{cite news |title=John Boehner: I'm 'not qualified' to debate climate change |date=May 29, 2014 |first=Aliyah |last=Frumin |url=http://www.msnbc.com/msnbc/boehner-not-qualified-debate-climate-change |accessdate=March 20, 2015 |publisher=[[MSNBC]]}}{{cite news|title=Why Republicans Keep Telling Everyone They're Not Scientists|first=Coral|last=Davenport|date=October 30, 2014|newspaper=[[New York Times]]|accessdate=March 20, 2015|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/10/31/us/why-republicans-keep-telling-everyone-theyre-not-scientists.html}} In 2011, Boehner opposed the NATO-led [[2011 military intervention in Libya|military intervention in Libya]]."[http://edition.cnn.com/2011/POLITICS/06/22/war.powers.libya/ Boehner: House not with McCain on Libya campaign]". CNN. June 22, 2011. In 2015, Boehner supported the [[Saudi Arabian-led intervention in Yemen]], saying: "I applaud the Saudis for taking this action to protect their homeland and to protect their own neighborhood."{{cite news|url=https://www.usnews.com/news/articles/2015/03/27/saudi-arabia-gets-bipartisan-backing-for-yemen-airstrikes |title=Saudi Arabia Gets Bipartisan Backing for Yemen Airstrikes |work=U.S. News. |date=March 27, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150328004338/http://www.usnews.com/news/articles/2015/03/27/saudi-arabia-gets-bipartisan-backing-for-yemen-airstrikes |archivedate=March 28, 2015 |df= }} === Financial crisis === On September 18, 2008, Congressman Boehner attended a closed meeting with congressional leaders, then-Treasury Secretary [[Henry Paulson]] and [[Chair of the Federal Reserve|Federal Reserve Chairman]] [[Ben Bernanke]], and was urged to craft legislation to help financially troubled banks. That same day (trade effective the next day), Congressman Boehner cashed out of an equity mutual fund.[http://www.marketplace.org/topics/economy/lawmakers-inside-advantage-trading "Lawmakers' inside advantage to trading"] ''Marketplace.'' September 17, 2009. Retrieved September 20, 2009 [[File:President Obama & John Boehner debt ceiling negotions. JPG.JPG|thumb|left|Speaker Boehner meets with President Obama at the White House during the 2011 debt ceiling increase negotiations]] On October 3, 2008 Boehner voted in favor of the [[Troubled Asset Relief Program]] (TARP),[http://clerk.house.gov/evs/2008/roll681.xml Emergency Economic Stabilization Act of 2008] Office of the Clerk of the U.S. House of Representatives. October 3, 2008. believing that [[Article One of the United States Constitution|the enumerated powers]] grant Congress the authority to "purchase assets and equity from financial institutions in order to strengthen its financial sector." Boehner has been highly critical of several initiatives by the Democratic Congress and President [[Barack Obama]], including the "[[cap and trade]]" plan that Boehner says would hurt job growth in his congressional district and elsewhere. He opposed the [[Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act]] and said that, if Republicans took control of the House of Representatives in the 2010 elections, they would do whatever it takes to stop the act. One option would be to defund the administrative aspect of the Act, not paying "one dime" to pay the salaries of the workers who would administer the plan. He also led an opposition to the 2009 stimulus and to Obama's first budget proposal, promoting instead an alternative economic recovery plan{{cite web|url=http://republicanleader.house.gov/News/DocumentSingle.aspx?DocumentID=109659 |title=House GOP Economic Recovery Alternative Will Create 6.2 Million New American Jobs | Republican Leader John Boehner |publisher=Republicanleader.house.gov |accessdate=June 14, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100608232152/http://republicanleader.house.gov/News/DocumentSingle.aspx?DocumentID=109659 |archivedate=June 8, 2010 }} and a Republican budget (authored by Ranking Rep. [[Paul Ryan (politician)|Paul Ryan]], R-[[Wisconsin|WI]]).{{cite web|url=http://www.house.gov/budget_republicans/hbcrepbudget.shtml |title=Budget Committee Republicans, U.S. House of Representatives, Washington, D.C |publisher=House.gov |date=January 4, 2009 |accessdate=June 14, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100306115414/http://www.house.gov/budget_republicans/hbcrepbudget.shtml |archivedate=March 6, 2010 }} He has advocated for an across-the-board [[budget freeze|spending freeze]], including [[entitlement programs]]. Boehner favors making changes in [[Social Security (United States)|Social Security]], such as by raising the retirement age to 70 for people who have at least 20 years until retirement, as well as tying cost-of-living increases to the [[consumer price index]] rather than [[inflation|wage inflation]], and limiting payments to those who need them.{{Citation| last = Wereschagin| first = Mike| last2 = Zito| first2 = Salena| title = Obama's good for GOP, Boehner says| newspaper = [[Pittsburgh Tribune-Review]]| date = June 29, 2010| url = http://pittsburghlive.com/x/pittsburghtrib/news/s_688102.html| accessdate = September 12, 2010| deadurl = yes| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100702154122/http://www.pittsburghlive.com/x/pittsburghtrib/news/s_688102.html| archivedate = July 2, 2010| df = mdy-all}} In 2011, Boehner called the [[No Taxpayer Funding for Abortion Act]] "one of our highest legislative priorities."Somashekhar, Sandhya. [https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/01/31/AR2011013105207.html "Legislative proposal puts abortion rights supporters on alert."] ''Washington Post'', February 1, 2011.Boehner, John. [http://www.speaker.gov/News/DocumentSingle.aspx?DocumentID=220673 Boehner press release on HR 3] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110204081738/http://www.speaker.gov/News/DocumentSingle.aspx?DocumentID=220673 |date=February 4, 2011 }} January 20, 2011. In 2013, Boehner led his caucus in a strategy to hold Defense spending hostage in order to avoid reducing the deficit with revenue increases.{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/lorenthompson/2013/02/04/republicans-target-their-own-voters-in-defense-budget-switch/ |title=Republicans Target Their Own Voters In Defense Budget Switch |publisher=Forbes |date=January 18, 2012 |accessdate=October 28, 2013}} == Political campaigns == === 2006 === {{See also|United States House of Representatives elections in Ohio, 2006#District 8}} In the [[United States House elections, 2006|November 2006 election]], Boehner defeated the Democratic Party candidate, [[U.S. Air Force]] [[veteran]] Mort Meier, 64% to 36%.{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/ELECTION/2006//pages/results/states/OH/index.html|title=State Races: Ohio 2006 Elections|publisher=CNN|date= November 2006|accessdate =March 16, 2006}} === 2008 === {{See also|United States House of Representatives elections in Ohio, 2008#District 8}} In the [[United States House elections, 2008|November 2008 election]], Boehner defeated Nicholas Von Stein, 68% to 32%.{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/ELECTION/2008/results/state/#OH |title=State Election Results |date= January 12, 2009 |publisher=CNN |accessdate=November 22, 2010}} === 2010 === {{See also|United States House of Representatives elections in Ohio, 2010#District 8}} Boehner was opposed by Democratic nominee [[Justin Coussoule]], [[Constitution Party (United States)|Constitution Party]] nominee Jim Condit, and [[Libertarian Party (United States)|Libertarian]] nominee David Harlow; but won the 2010 election.[http://www.sos.state.oh.us/sos/upload/elections/2010/gen/usrep.pdf Official candidate list] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110614222218/http://www.sos.state.oh.us/sos/upload/elections/2010/gen/usrep.pdf |date=June 14, 2011 }}, Ohio Secretary of State As Republican House Leader, Boehner was a Democratic target for criticism of Republican views and political positions. Post-speakership == === Politics === Boehner made headlines in April 2016 when he referred to [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] presidential candidate [[Ted Cruz]] as "[[Lucifer]] in the flesh" in an interview at [[Stanford University]].{{cite news|last1=Peterson|first1=Kristina|title=John Boehner Calls Ted Cruz 'Lucifer in the Flesh'|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/washwire/2016/04/28/john-boehner-calls-ted-cruz-lucifer-in-the-flesh/|accessdate=28 April 2016|publisher=The Wall Street Journal|date=28 April 2016}} On May 12, after [[Donald Trump]] became the presumptive Republican nominee, Boehner's support for him became public, though he distanced himself on several policies and expressed satisfaction with Cruz not securing the nomination: "Thank God the guy from Texas didn't win."{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2016/05/12/politics/john-boehner-backs-donald-trump/|date=May 12, 2016|publisher=CNN|title=John Boehner backs Donald Trump, thanks God Cruz didn't win|first=Phil|last=Mattingly}} On February 23, 2017, Boehner predicted Republicans would "fix" the Affordable Care Act and give it a different name as opposed to their stated intent to repeal and replace.{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2017/02/23/politics/john-boehner-obamacare/|title=Boehner: Obamacare repeal and replace 'not what's going to happen'|date=February 24, 2017|publisher=CNN|first=Terence|last=Burlij}} === Business === Boehner joined the board of tobacco company [[Reynolds American]] on September 15, 2016.{{cite web|last=Egan |first=Matt |url=http://money.cnn.com/2016/09/15/investing/john-boehner-smoking-joins-tobacco-company/ |title=Heavy smoker John Boehner joins tobacco company's board - Sep. 15, 2016 |publisher=Money.cnn.com |date=2016-09-15 |accessdate=2017-03-01}} In 2018, John Boehner announced his joining the board of Acreage Holdings, a [[Cannabis (drug)|cannabis]] corporation, to "promote the use of [[Medical cannabis in the United States|medical marijuana]]" and to advocate for federal [[Decriminalization of non-medical cannabis in the United States|decriminalization]] of it, a shift in his previously adamant opposition to [[cannabis in the United States|cannabis]] legalization.{{cite web|last1=Gstalter|first1=Morgan|title=Boehner joins cannabis company board to push for medical use|url=http://thehill.com/blogs/blog-briefing-room/news/382614-boehner-joins-board-of-cannabis-company-for-push-for-medical|website=The Hill|accessdate=11 April 2018}} == Legacy == In reporting his pending retirement, [[Politico]] summarized his Speakership: :Boehner came into power on the momentum of the 2010 tea party wave. But it was that movement that gave him constant problems. He clashed with [[Social conservatism|social conservatives]] over the debt limit, government funding, Obamacare and taxes. But his tenure will also be remembered for his complicated relationship with President Barack Obama. He and Obama tried — but repeatedly failed — to cut a deal on a sweeping fiscal agreement. But Boehner has had some significant victories, including the trade deal that Congress passed this year, and changes to entitlement programs.Jake Sherman, Anna Palmer, John Bresnahan and Lauren French, "Speaker John Boehner retiring from Congress at the end of October" [http://www.politico.com/story/2015/09/speaker-john-boehner-retiring-from-congress-at-the-end-of-october-214056#ixzz3mlVEHpBf ''POLITICO'' Sept. 25, 2015] Paul Kane in the ''Washington Post'' emphasizes how none of the "big deals" he sought were ever reached: :Boehner never landed the really big deal he craved. Not the $4 trillion tax-and-entitlement deal he reached for in 2011, not the repackaged version a year later and not the immigration overhaul he sought in 2014.Paul Kane, "After nearly five years, Boehner could never land the 'big deal' he wanted" [https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/after-nearly-five-years-boehner-could-never-land-the-big-deal-he-wanted/2015/09/25/6bf22bd2-63b3-11e5-b38e-06883aacba64_story.html ''Washington Post'' Sept 25, 2015] Furthermore, Kane argues, Boehner's persona alienated conservative Republicans who demanded more vigorous attacks on Obama and instead perceived, "a country club Republican who loved to play 18 holes of golf and drink merlot afterward while cutting deals. In an era of shouting and confrontation, on talk radio or cable TV, Boehner's easygoing style did not fit."Paul Kane, "After nearly five years, Boehner could never land the 'big deal' he wanted" == Personal life == Boehner and his wife Debbie were married in 1973, and live in the [[Wetherington, Ohio|Wetherington]] section of [[West Chester Township, Butler County, Ohio|West Chester Township]]. They have two daughters, Lindsay and Tricia.{{cite journal|author=James Rowley |date=October 28, 2010 |title=Boehner's Blue-Collar Roots Frame Possible Next Speaker's Views |journal=Business Week {{Infobox person | name = Lawrence Bender | image = LawrenceBenderIBAug09.jpg | caption = Bender at a premiere for
''[[Inglourious Basterds]]'' in August 2009 | birthname = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|mf=yes|1957|10|17}} | birth_place = [[The Bronx]], [[New York City]] U.S. | occupation = Film producer | years_active = 1987–present | education = [[University of Maine]] }} '''Lawrence Bender''' (born October 17, 1957) is an American [[film producer]]. Throughout his career, Bender-produced films have received 36 [[Academy Awards|Academy Award]] nominations, resulting in eight wins.{{Cite web|url=http://www.environment.ucla.edu/people/lawrence-bender|title=Lawrence Bender, UCLA Institute of the Environment and Sustainability|website=www.environment.ucla.edu|access-date=2016-04-25}}{{cite web|url=https://losangelesballet.org/pdf/Gala_2017_Celebrities.pdf|title=Honoree Lawrence Bender}} Bender rose to fame by producing ''[[Reservoir Dogs]]'' in 1992 and has since produced all of [[Quentin Tarantino]]'s films with the exception of ''[[Death Proof]]'', ''[[Django Unchained]]'' and ''[[The Hateful Eight]]''. Bender has also produced three [[documentary film]]s, most notably ''[[An Inconvenient Truth]]'' (2006) which won the Academy Award for Best Documentary Feature.{{cite web|url=https://www.fastcompany.com/3061093/steve-golin-and-lawrence-bender-talk-about-how-film-can-drive-cultural-change|title=Steve Golin and Lawrence Bender Talk About How Film Can Drive Cultural Change}} He has received three [[Academy Award for Best Picture|Best Picture]] nominations for producing ''[[Pulp Fiction]]'', ''[[Good Will Hunting]]'' and ''[[Inglourious Basterds]]''. ==Early life== Bender was born to a [[American Jews|Jewish]] family in The Bronx, New York, and grew up in New Jersey, where his father was a college history professor and his mother was a kindergarten teacher.[http://la-confidential-magazine.com/celebrities/articles/from-israel-with-love L.A. Confidential: "Lawrence Bender Loves Israel" By Lawrence Bender] retrieved May 25, 2015 In high school, he decided to pursue a career as a civil engineer. His grandfather had been a civil engineer and he heard there were good jobs available in the field.{{cite web|url=http://www.pressherald.com/life/audience/high-production-values_2013-05-05.html|title=Hollywood film producer credits UMaine|date=5 May 2013|publisher=}} He is a graduate of The University of Maine, Class of 1979, majoring in Civil Engineering.{{cite web |url=http://umaine.edu/commencement/speakers/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-05-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130510171500/http://umaine.edu/commencement/speakers/ |archivedate=2013-05-10 |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://bangordailynews.com/2013/04/23/living/umaine-alum-hollywood-producer-bender-to-give-commencement-address/|title=UMaine alum, Hollywood producer Bender to give commencement address|publisher=}} While attending U-Maine, Bender acquired a passion for dance. After graduating, Bender pursued dancing and was awarded a scholarship to the [[Louis Falco]] dance troupe.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/09/22/movies/a-film-maker-and-the-art-of-the-deal.html|title=A Film Maker and the Art of the Deal}} He worked as a dancer for some time before a series of injuries ended his dance career. == Career == ===Film=== In the 1980s, he worked as a [[Grip (job)|grip]] on the syndicated anthology series ''[[Tales from the Darkside]]''. In 1989, he produced the film ''[[Intruder (1989 film)|Intruder]]'', in which leading roles are [[Sam Raimi]] and [[Bruce Campbell]]. After meeting Tarantino in 1990 and being given the script for ''[[Reservoir Dogs]]'', he agreed to produce the film, which went on to achieve commercial success.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/09/22/movies/a-film-maker-and-the-art-of-the-deal.html|title=A Film Maker and the Art of the Deal|work=The New York Times|last=Weinraub|first=Bernard|date=1994|accessdate=May 11, 2018}} Throughout the 1990s, Bender also produced ''[[Pulp Fiction]]'' (1994), ''[[Killing Zoe]]'' (1994), ''[[Fresh (1994 film)|Fresh]]'', ''[[White Man's Burden (film)|White Man's Burden]]'' (1995), ''[[From Dusk Till Dawn]]'' (1996), ''[[Jackie Brown]]'' (1997), ''[[Good Will Hunting]]'' (1997), ''[[A Price Above Rubies]]'' (1998), and ''[[Anna and the King]]'' (1999). In the early 2000s, Bender produced the films, ''[[The Mexican]]'' (2001), ''[[Knockaround Guys]]'' (2001), ''[[Kill Bill: Volume 1]]'' (2003), ''[[Kill Bill: Volume 2]]'' (2004), ''[[Voces inocentes|Innocent Voices]]'' (2004), and ''[[Dirty Dancing: Havana Nights]]''. Since May 2005, Bender has been a contributing blogger at ''[[The Huffington Post]]''. In 2009, Lawrence produced the Tarantino film ''[[Inglourious Basterds]]'' which was nominated for an Academy Award for Best Picture.{{cite web|url=http://movieline.com/2009/10/23/lawrence-bender-the-movieline-interview/2/|title=Inglorious Basterds Producer Lawrence Bender: The Interview|work=Moveline|last=Abramovitch|first=Seth|date=October 23, 2009|accessdate=May 11, 2018}} He also produced the 2012 film ''[[Safe (2012 film)|Safe]]'', which starred [[Jason Statham]].{{cite web|url=http://www.indiewire.com/2012/04/safe-producer-lawrence-bender-talks-jason-stathams-appeal-why-he-didnt-produce-django-unchained-111297/|title='Safe' Producer Lawrence Bender Talks Jason Stathan's Appeal & Why He Didn't Produce 'Django Unchained'|work=IndieWire|last=Taylor|first=Drew|date=April 26, 2012|accessdate=May 11, 2018}} In 2016, he was executive producer for ''[[The Forest (2016 film)|The Forest]]'', [[Martin Scorsese]]'s ''[[Silence (2016 film)|Silence]]'' and [[Mel Gibson]]'s ''[[Hacksaw Ridge]]''.{{cite web|url=https://www.ioes.ucla.edu/person/lawrence-bender/|title=Lawrence Bender}} In 2017, it was announced that Bender would serve as a producer for the film ''The Widow''.{{cite web|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/cannes-isabelle-huppert-chloe-grace-moretz-star-thriller-widow-1000624|title=Cannes: Isabell Huppert, Chloe Grace Moretz to Star in Thriller 'The Widow'|work=The Hollywood Reporter|last=Ford|first=Rebecca|date=May 5, 2017|accessdate=May 24, 2018}} In early 2018, there was an allegation of a "cover up" over an on-set car crash during the filming of ''Kill Bill''.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-5365887/Kill-Bill-producer-apologizes-Uma-Thurman-crash.html|title=Kill Bill Producer Apologizes to Uma Thurman But Insists He 'Never Hid' the Horrific Tarantino Movie Crash that Occurred On Set|work=Daily Mail|last1=Schroeder|first1=Jessa|last2=Smith|first2=Jennifer|date=February 7, 2018|accessdate=May 24, 2018}} In February 2018, it was announced that Bender would serve as a producer on for the Al Capone biopic ''[[Fonzo (film)|Fonzo]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.nola.com/movies/index.ssf/2018/02/tom_hardys_al_capone_movie_fon.html|title=Tom Hardy's Al Capone Movie 'Fonzo' Prepping to Film in New Orleans|work=The Times-Picayune|last=Scott|first=Mike|date=February 22, 2018|accessdate=May 24, 2018}} Bender makes [[cameo appearance]] in many of the films he produces: he was a police officer chasing Mr. Pink in ''[[Reservoir Dogs]]'', a restaurant patron billed as a "Long Hair Yuppie-Scum" in ''[[Fresh (1994 film)|Fresh]]'', ''[[Pulp Fiction]]'' and ''[[Four Rooms]]'', a hotel clerk in ''Kill Bill: Volume 2'', and as a bartender in ''Safe''. ===Documentaries=== He produced the 2006 documentary ''[[An Inconvenient Truth]]'', which raised unprecedented awareness about climate change, won the Academy Award for Best Documentary Feature.{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2016/biz/news/an-inconvenient-truth-global-warming-jeff-skoll-1201760431/|title=Participant's Jeff Skoll: How the Power of Film Spread 'An Inconvenient Truth'|work=Variety|last=Skoll|first=Jeff|date=April 27, 2016|accessdate=May 24, 2018}} In 2008, Bender was a founding member of the [[World Security Institute]] campaign, [[Global Zero (campaign)|Global Zero]].{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/07/18/movies/18nuclear.html|title=It's Time to Start Worrying Again}} His 2010 documentary, ''[[Countdown to Zero]]'', features [[Tony Blair]], Presidents, Musharef, Gorbachev, De Klerk and Carter among others, details the urgent risk posed by proliferation, terrorism, and accidental use of nuclear weapons.{{cite web|url=https://www.politico.com/click/stories/1004/thumbs_up_for_bender_nuclear_doc.html|title=Thumbs Up For Bender Nuclear Doc|work=Politico|last=Schroeder Mullins|first=Anne|date=April 6, 2010|accessdate=May 24, 2018}} Bender was an executive producer for the 2017 sequel to ''An Inconvenient Truth'', ''[[An Inconvenient Sequel: Truth to Power]]''.{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2017/06/an-inconvenient-sequel-release-date-al-gore-climate-change-paramount-1201889731/|title='An Inconvenient Sequel' Getting Limited Summer Release From Paramount - Update|work=Deadline Hollywood|last=Pedersen|first=Erik|date=June 1, 2017|accessdate=May 24, 2018}} ===Television=== In the early 2000s, Bender formed a partnership with Kevin Kelly Brown and created the production company Bender Brown Productions. The company produced the CBS Drama ''[[Dr. Vegas]]'' and the [[Syfy]] channel mini-series ''Earthsea''.{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2012/08/lawrence-bender-kevin-browns-company-signs-pod-deal-with-universal-cable-prods-311474/|title=Lawrence Bender & Kevin Brown's Company Sings Pod Deal With Universal Cable Prods.|work=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|last=Andreeva|first=Nellie|date=August 1, 2012|accessdate=May 24, 2018}} In 2008, it was reported that Bender was working with [[Nine Inch Nails]]' [[Trent Reznor]] to create a television series based on the 2007 album ''[[Year Zero (album)|Year Zero]]''.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/06/08/arts/music/08pare.html|title=Frustration and Fury: Take It. It’s Free.|publisher=''[[The New York Times]]''|last=Pareles|first=Jon|date=June 8, 2008|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5YUa9v4NA|archivedate=June 11, 2008|accessdate=June 8, 2008|deadurl=yes|df=}} Bender produced the 2015 [[Starz]] miniseries ''[[Flesh and Bone (miniseries)|Flesh and Bone]]''.{{cite web|url=https://www.thrillist.com/entertainment/nation/lawrence-bender-interview-pulp-fiction-producer-talks-flesh-and-bone-quentin-tarantino|title='Pulp Fiction' Producer Lawrence Bender On Trading Bullets For Ballet With 'Flesh and Bone'|work=Thrillist|last=Charaipotra|first=Sona|date=November 4, 2015|accessdate=May 24, 2018}} In 2017, it was announced that Bender and Brown would executive produce a reboot pilot of the television series ''[[Roswell (TV series)|Roswell]]'' for [[The CW]].{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2017/10/roswell-reboot-with-immigration-twist-the-cw-amblin-tv-1202187242/|title='Roswell' Reboot With Immigration Twist In Works At the CW From Amblin TV|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|last=Andreeva|first=Nellie|date=October 12, 2017|accessdate=July 30, 2018}} The CW ordered ''[[Roswell, New Mexico (TV series)|Roswell, New Mexico]]'' to series in May 2018.{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2018/05/the-cw-picks-up-charmed-roswell-reboots-tvd-originals-offshoot-ilegacies-n-the-dark-greg-berlanti-pilot-to-series-1202388840/|title=The CW Picks Up ‘Charmed’ & ‘Roswell’ Reboots, ‘TVD’/’Originals Offshoot, ‘In The Dark’ & Greg Berlanti Pilot To Series|last=Petski|first=Denise|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|date=May 11, 2018|accessdate=May 11, 2018}} Bender also executive produced the 2018 [[Netflix]] series ''[[Seven Seconds (TV series)|Seven Seconds]]''.{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2018/tv/reviews/seven-seconds-review-crime-drama-veena-sud-netflix-1202707783/|title=TV Review: 'Seven Seconds' On Netflix|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|last=Ryan|first=Maureen|date=February 22, 2018|accessdate=May 24, 2018}} == Personal life == Bender is also a passionate social and political activist and supports many causes.{{cite web|url=http://jewishjournal.com/culture/arts/71907/|title=The Other Avenger: Tarantino's Producer Lawrence Bender}} Bender serves on the board of [[Creative Coalition|The Creative Coalition]]. He is a member of Council on Foreign Relations the Pacific Council. Bender is also on the Advisory Board for the UCLA Institute of the Environment and Sustainability and a member of the Global Zero campaign.[http://www.environment.ucla.edu/people/board.php UCLA Institute of the Environment and Sustainability]{{YouTube|a0NBSHOQvYc|Lawrence Bender on His Involvement with the UCLA IoES}} In 2004, Bender was a top fundraiser for [[John Kerry presidential campaign, 2004|John Kerry's presidential campaign]].{{cite web|url=https://grist.org/article/bender/|title=A Chat With Inconvenient Truth Co-Producer and Hollywood Bigwig Lawrence Bender}} He was also an early supporter of [[Barack Obama presidential campaign, 2008|Barack Obama's 2008 presidential campaign]].{{cite web|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/washington/2009/05/barack-obama-hollywood-dnc.html|title=Barack Obama to Hollywood: Without You, No Obama White House}} On May 11, 2013, he returned to The University of Maine to receive an honorary Doctor of Humane Letters degree and share remarks during the 2013 Commencement ceremonies. ==Awards and recognition== In 1994, ''Pulp Fiction'' won the [[Palme d'Or]] award at the [[Cannes Film Festival]].{{cite web|url=https://film.avclub.com/pulp-fiction-brought-guns-gimps-and-glory-to-the-cann-1798271458|title=Pulp Fiction Brought Guns, Gimps and Glory to the Cannes Film Festival}} Bender received a producer of the year award at the Cannes Film Festival in 2001, becoming the third person ever to win the award and the first American to do so.{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2001/film/awards/bender-feted-as-producer-of-the-year-1117799201/|title=Bender Feted as Producer of the Year}} In 2005, Bender was presented with the Torch of Liberty award from the [[American Civil Liberties Union|ACLU]].{{cite web|url=https://umaine.edu/news/blog/2013/04/04/2013-commencement-honorary-degree-recipient-and-speaker-lawrence-bender/|title=2013 Commencement Honorary Degree Recipient and Speaker Lawrence Bender}} He was named a Wildlife Hero by the [[National Wildlife Federation]] in 2011.{{cite web|url=https://www.columbuszoo.org/home/about/press-releases/press-release-articles/2011/06/16/jack-hanna-honored-by-the-national-wildlife-federation|title=Jack Hannah Honored By the National Wildlife Federation}} Throughout his career, films Bender has produced or executive produced have won a total of eight Academy Awards. ==Filmography== ===Film=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Alicia Blanco Villegas |residence = [[Quinta de Olivos]] |profession = [[Civil engineer]] |website = {{url|mauriciomacri.com.ar|Official website}} |signature = MacriSignature.png }} '''Mauricio Macri'''{{cite web |title=Biografía del Presidente Mauricio Macri |url=https://www.casarosada.gob.ar/el-presidente/biografia |website=Casa Rosada |language=es-es}} ({{IPA-es|mauˈɾisjo ˈmakɾi}}; born February 8, 1959) is the current [[President of Argentina|President]] of [[Argentina]] and has been in office since 2015. A former [[civil engineering|civil engineer]], Macri won the first presidential [[Two-round system|runoff]] [[Ballotage in Argentina|ballotage]] in Argentina's history (the runoff system had been introduced in 1994) and is the first democratically-elected non-[[Radical Civic Union|Radical]] or [[Justicialist Party|Peronist]] president since 1916.{{cite web|url=http://www.losandes.com.ar/article/mauricio-macri-el-primer-presidente-desde-1916-que-no-es-peronista-ni-radical|title=Mauricio Macri, el primer presidente desde 1916 que no es peronista ni radical|date=22 November 2015|publisher=Los Andes|language=es}} He was [[List of mayors and chiefs of government of Buenos Aires|chief of government of Buenos Aires]] from 2007 to 2015, and represented [[Buenos Aires|the city]] in the [[Argentine Chamber of Deputies|lower house]] of the [[National Congress of Argentina|Congress of Argentina]] from 2005 to 2007. The reintegration of Argentina into the international community is central to Macri's agenda. Born in Tandil, [[Buenos Aires Province]], Macri is the son of [[Francesco Macri]], a prominent [[Italian people|Italian]] businessman in the industrial and construction sectors, and was raised in an [[upper class]] home. He received a [[bachelor's degree]] in civil engineering from the [[Pontifical Catholic University of Argentina]] and studied at [[Columbia Business School]] in [[New York City]].{{cite news|title=Qué estudiaron y a qué universidades fueron los candidatos a Presidente|url=http://www.girabsas.com/nota/13864/|accessdate=7 October 2015|work=Girabsas|date=7 October 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151012013732/http://www.girabsas.com/nota/13864/|archivedate=12 October 2015|df=dmy-all}} Macri became president of [[Boca Juniors]], one of Argentina's two most popular football clubs, in 1995. In 2005, he created the [[Centre-right politics|centre-right]] [[Republican Proposal]] party (Propuesta Republicana, also known as PRO).{{cite news|title=Los momentos de Mauricio Macri en Boca que marcaron su perfil político |url=http://www.infobae.com/2015/11/23/1771739-los-momentos-mauricio-macri-boca-que-marcaron-su-perfil-politico|accessdate=23 November 2015|work=Girabsas|date=23 November 2015}} Although Macri was a potential presidential candidate in the [[Argentine general election, 2011|2011 general elections]], he ran instead for reelection as mayor. He received about 47 percent of the vote in the mayoral election, which led to a [[Two-round system|runoff]] election on 31 July 2011 against [[Daniel Filmus]] in which Macri was reelected for a second consecutive term.{{Cite web|title=El jefe de gobierno fue reelecto por amplio margen|url=http://www.lanacion.com.ar/1393853-macri-y-filmus-se-enfrentan-una-eleccion-con-alto-impacto-a-nivel-nacional|website=www.lanacion.com.ar|accessdate=24 November 2015}} On 22 November 2015, after a tie in the first round of the [[Argentine general election, 2015|presidential elections on 25 October]], he received 51.34 percent of the vote to defeat [[Front for Victory]] candidate [[Daniel Scioli]]{{cite news|title=Balotaje: terminó el escrutinio definitivo y Macri ganó por una menor ventaja |url=http://www.minutouno.com/notas/1456464-balotaje-termino-el-escrutinio-definitivo-y-macri-gano-una-menor-ventaja|accessdate=10 December 2015|work=minutouno|date=10 December 2015}} and was inaugurated on 10 December 2015 in the Argentine Congress.{{cite news|title=Así juró Macri en el Congreso|url=http://tn.com.ar/politica/asi-juro-macri-en-el-congreso_641107|accessdate=10 December 2015|work=Todo Noticias|date=10 December 2015}} In 2016, Macri was named one of the [[Time 100|world's 100 most influential people]] and the most powerful president in [[Latin America]] by the U.S. news magazine ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]''.{{cite web|url=http://time.com/collection/2016-time-100/|publisher=time.com|title=List of individuals included in the ''TIME'' 100 in 2016 |accessdate=26 April 2017}}{{cite news|title="Time" incluyó a Macri entre las 100 personas más influyentes del mundo|url=http://tn.com.ar/politica/time-incluyo-macri-entre-las-100-personas-mas-influyentes-del-mundo_667489|accessdate=21 April 2016|work=Todo Noticias|date=21 April 2016}} ==Early life== Macri was born in [[Tandil]] in the province of Buenos Aires, the son of Italian-born tycoon [[Francisco Macri|Fracisco "Franco" Macri]] (owner of the [[Philco]] affiliate in Argentina) and Alicia Blanco-Villegas Cinque.{{cite web |url= http://www.lanacion.com.ar/1947637-quien-es-alicia-blanco-villegas-la-madre-de-mauricio-macri|title= ¿Quién es Alicia Blanco Villegas, la madre de Mauricio Macri?|trans-title= Who is Alicia Blanco-Villegas, the mother of Mauricio Macri?|language= Spanish|author= |date= 16 October 2016|publisher= La Nación|accessdate=22 November 2016}} The family moved to Buenos Aires a short time later, and kept their houses in Tandil as [[Holiday cottage|vacation properties]]. His father, and his uncle Jorge Blanco Villegas, influenced Macri to become a businessman, and Franco expected his son to succeed him as leader of his firms. Macri preferred his uncle's company to constant scrutiny by his father. He was educated at [[Colegio Cardenal Newman]],[http://www.lanacion.com.ar/1849283-los-amigos-de-macri-del-cardenal-newman-y-la-empresa-al-poder "Los amigos de Macri: del Cardenal Newman y la empresa, al poder", ''La Nacion'', 27 November 2015.] (Retrieved 17 June 2016) and received a bachelor's degree in civil engineering from the [[Pontifical Catholic University of Argentina]] (UCA). At this time Macri became interested in [[neoliberalism]] and joined the now-defunct [[Union of the Democratic Centre (Argentina)|Union of the Democratic Centre]] and a [[think tank]] led by former minister [[Álvaro Alsogaray]].''Todo Macri'', pp. 8-10 In 1985, he briefly attended [[Columbia Business School]], the [[Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania]] and the [[Universidad del CEMA]] in [[Buenos Aires]].[http://www.cema.edu.ar/cgc/download/2004/cvmacri.pdf Mauricio Macri's curriculum vitae], CEMA; accessed 23 November 2015. Macri's professional experience began at SIDECO Americana, a construction company which was part of his father's Socma Group [[holding company]], where he worked for three years as a junior analyst and became a senior analyst. In 1984, he worked in the credit department of [[Citibank]] Argentina in Buenos Aires. Macri joined Socma Group the same year, and became its general manager in 1985. In 1992, he became vice president of [[Sevel Argentina]] (then manufacturing [[Fiat]] and [[Peugeot]] automobiles under licence in Argentina as part of Socma), and became president two years later. In 1991, Macri was kidnapped for 12 days by officers of the [[Policía Federal Argentina|Argentine Federal Police]]. Kept in a small room with a [[chemical toilet]] and a hole in the roof to receive food, he was freed when his family reportedly paid a multimillion-dollar ransom.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1991/12/08/world/argentina-finds-a-kidnapping-ring-of-policemen.html|title=Argentina Finds a Kidnapping Ring of Policemen |publisher=New York Times|accessdate=2 January 2016}} Macri has said that the ordeal led him to enter politics.{{cite web |url= https://www.newstalk.com/Kidnapped-former-football-club-who-is-Argentinas-new-president|title= Kidnapped by police and the former chief executive of a football club: who is Argentina's new president?|author= Adrian Collins|date= November 23, 2015|publisher= News Talk|accessdate=November 7, 2018}} [[File:The Rolling Stones with Macri 02.jpg|thumb|Macri and his wife Juliana and their daughter with [[The Rolling Stones]], February 2016]] His first wife was Ivonne Bordeu, daughter of race-car driver [[Juan Manuel Bordeu]]. They had three sons: Agustina, Jimena and Francisco. After they divorced, Macri married model [[Isabel Menditeguy]] in 1994; Franco requested a [[prenuptial agreement]]. Although the marriage reached a crisis when Macri became chairman of Boca Juniors, they did not divorce until 2005. He began a romance with María Laura Groba which did not lead to marriage. Macri left Groba in 2010, began a relationship with businesswoman [[Juliana Awada]]{{cite web |url= https://www.clarin.com/sociedad/bellas-mujeres-pareja-Mauricio-Macri_0_H1CxltvQx.html|title= Las bellas mujeres que fueron pareja de Mauricio Macri|trans-title= The nice women who were couples of Mauricio Macri|language= Spanish|author= |date= 22 November 2015|publisher= Clarín|accessdate=1 December 2016}} and married Awada that year. At the wedding reception, he wore a fake moustache as part of his impersonation of singer [[Freddie Mercury]]. Macri accidentally swallowed the moustache, and Minister of Health [[Jorge Lemus]] performed [[first aid]] to save his life.{{cite web |url= http://www.elintransigente.com/argentina/2010/11/22/macri-trago-bigote-vivieron-momentos-panico-casamiento-62061.html|title= Macri, se tragó el bigote y se vivieron momentos de pánico en su casamiento|trans-title= Macri, swallowed a mustache and lived moments of panic at his wedding|language= Spanish|author= |date= 22 November 2010|publisher= El Intransigente|accessdate=5 May 2017}}{{cite web |url= http://www.newsweek.com/who-mauricio-macri-argentinas-new-president-403465|title= Who is Mauricio Macri, Argentina’s New President?|author= Moore, Jack|publisher= Newsweek|date=11 December 2015|accessdate=5 May 2017}} ==Boca Juniors== Macri intended to run for chairman of Boca Juniors in 1991, but his father convinced him to keep working at Sevel. He tried to buy the [[Deportivo Español]] team, but could not get support from the team's board of directors. Macri supported [[Boca Juniors]], paying coach [[César Luis Menotti]]'s salary and buying players for the team (including [[forward (association football)|forward]] [[Walter Perazzo]]). Franco, skeptical about his son's prospects for success, finally allowed him to run Boca Juniors. He instructed aide [[Orlando Salvestrini]] to work with Mauricio for two reasons: to help him and to monitor his activities. Mauricio met with former Boca Juniors chairmen [[Antonio Alegre]] and [[Carlos Heller]], and tried to convince them to work with him; both rebuffed him. Macri later sought the support of other groups in Boca Juniors, eventually winning the team's internal elections in 1995 with 7058 votes.''Todo Macri'', pp. 29-33{{cite web |url=https://www.clarin.com/deportes/dia-goles-primera-victoria-macri_0_SyMg_YktDQx.html|title= El día de los 10 goles y la primera victoria de Macri|trans-title= The day of the 10 goals and the first victory of Macri|language= Spanish|author= Guillermo Dos Santos Coelho|date= December 3, 2015|publisher= Clarín|accessdate=November 8, 2018}} His first years were unsuccessful; the team's performance was poor, players frequently complained about salaries and bonuses, and Macri changed coaches three times. The only initial improvement was a partial reconstruction of the stadium. He arranged that the Boca Juniors institution worked in the [[stock exchange]], to earn enough money to buy new players. Macri's first coach was [[Carlos Salvador Bilardo]], who brought 14 new players to the team and finished the [[1996–97 Argentine Primera División#Torneo Apertura|1996 Apertura league]] in 10th place.{{cite web |url= http://www.ole.com.ar/boca-juniors/futbol/Boca-trajo-jugadores-salio-mitad_0_1303669672.html|title= En el 96 Boca trajo 15 jugadores y salió en la mitad|trans-title= In the '96 Boca brought 15 players and ended in the middle|language= Spanish|author= "En el 96 Boca trajo 15 jugadores y salió en la mitad"|date= 14 February 2015|publisher= Olé|accessdate=27 February 2016}} His second coach, [[Héctor Veira]], also performed poorly.{{cite web |url= http://www.lanacion.com.ar/111397-el-mejor-arranque-de-boca|title= El mejor arranque de Boca|trans-title= The best start of Boca|language= Spanish|first= Christian|last= Leblebidjian|date= 22 September 1998|publisher= La Nación|accessdate=27 February 2016}} New coach [[Carlos Bianchi]] helped [[Juan Román Riquelme]] improve his performance, and had [[Martín Palermo]] and [[Guillermo Barros Schelotto]] as effective forwards. They won the first two tournaments, beginning a record 40-match unbeaten run.{{cite web |url= https://tn.com.ar/deportes/esencial/cuanto-quedo-el-river-de-gallardo-del-record-invicto-del-boca-de-bianchi_902446|title= ¿A cuánto quedó el River de Gallardo del invicto del Boca de Bianchi?|trans-title= How far is River from the unbeaten's run of Bianchi's Boca?|language= Spanish|author= |date= October 3, 2018|publisher= TN|accessdate=November 7, 2018}} ==Political career== [[File:Mauricio Macri Foto de Prensa.jpg|thumb|alt=A smiling Macri in a light-blue shirt|Macri in 2007]] Macri made his political debut in 2003, founding the centre-right party [[Commitment to Change]] ({{lang-es|Compromiso para el Cambio}}).{{cite web |url= https://www.ft.com/content/62219644-5807-11e6-9f70-badea1b336d4|title= Interview: Argentine president Mauricio Macri looks to end confrontational politics|author= Benedict Mander|date= September 9, 2016|publisher= Financial Times|accessdate=November 6, 2018}} The party was intended to be a source of new politicians, since the major parties were discredited after the [[December 2001 riots in Argentina]].{{cite web |url= https://www.clarin.com/opinion/pro-cambiemos-macri-presidente-partidos-politicos_0_BkTdleFvXg.html|title= Macri y el PRO en el poder: una suma de novedades históricas|trans-title= Macri and the PRO in power: a sum of historical novelties|language= Spanish|author= Fabián Bosoer|date= November 23, 2015|publisher= Clarín|accessdate=November 6, 2018}} Later that year, Macri ran for mayor of Buenos Aires, alongside [[Horacio Rodríguez Larreta]].
